left-skewed due to the fact that
Number of identical words : 5
https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/the-fact-that
 the aFBAgent is sometimes able to achieve higher
commission percentages when a better aFTPAgent price has been settled or the
aCAgent is more easily satisfied.

Figure 1.4.4: ICNET Broker Commission Percentage Histogram

Hence, the above experiments demonstrate that using ICNETprotocol in our
agent-based solution for freight transport canbehave realistically andmanifest sim-
ilar results to human-conducted negotiation.

35

1.5 AICNETNegotiation

1.5.1 Introduction

In this section we propose new computational approaches to endow negotiation
brokerswithnovel and controllable instruments aiming tobetter impact their busi-
ness environment, by providing them with quantitative feedback regarding their
decisions. Generally speaking, the vastmajority of negotiationprotocols only con-
sider short-term advantages of participants, like for examplemonetary benefits, by
aiming to increase the profit per negotiation of the broker and/or other participant
agents. This is the case of our experiments with ICNET protocol, detailed in sec-
tion 1.4, where only the monetary value of goods played a role in the negotiation
mechanism. However, we consider that this is of limited value since the business
world is far more complex and with many facets of the longer-term benefits one
might gather by engaging in negotiations.

Let us consider awell known fact in economy: monopolies are bad for an open
market since the broker and the entire market environment is at the hand of a sin-
gle actor. The monopoly holder establishes the monetary value and the pace of
evolution, see for example the caseof StandardOil [147]
. Hence, brokers/markets
need to prevent the rise ofmonopolies. This phenomenon canbe controlled either
through regulatory bodies and/or through active preemptive strategies, the latter
approach being considered in this section. Since, monopoly hindering strategies
that involve only adjustments to themonetary value are ineffective, as amonopoly
will diminish the value of goods/services in order to hinder potential competition
in the short term and to gain monopoly in the medium to longer term [182]
, a
need for a broader set of actions emerges.

Hence, ourmotivation is to design an enhancednegotiation protocol such that
the broker can dynamically and easily employ complex strategies of domain spe-
cific (transport and logistics in our case) social inspiration. For example, a strat-
egy for hindering monopolies might consider favouring smaller / less important
transporters over larger / more important transporters when their bids are the
same or marginally different. Also, sometime might be better to encourage trans-
porters that havemultiple transport capabilities in order to reduce the dependence

36

of rather few highly specialised transporters.
Since thisworkheavily relies onexperimental evaluationofnegotiations, itwas

vital to create an accurate scientific representation of the negotiation environment
and processes. We have successfully created a simulation system / experimental
systemby using concepts and computationalmethods borrowed from the fields of
ComplexNetworksAnalysis (CNA)[207]
andMulti-Agent Systems (MAS) [79]
.
The simulation systemwas developed using Python programming language. Also,
we have also utilisedGephi [19]
for graph visualisation and exploration. The code
of ES is publicly available on Github12 for those interested to use and further de-
velop it, underMIT license. We recommend using the code in Jupyter/IPython 13

interactive development environment, as it was developed to be used as such. The
following subsections introduce the conceptual model of our experiments, as well
as the supporting experimental system (ES).

1.5.2 ConceptualModel

MAFTLS Graph Representation

In order to analyse social characteristics of agents involved inMAFTLS, we intro-
duce the methods used for representing the agents’ social environment. CNA de-
fines the structures used to represent such environments as networks, while SNA
often refers to them as sociograms. However, both are essentially graphs (as in
graph theory) augmented with specific information. Hence, we are using these
terms interchangeably.

Graphshave two typesof constituent elements: nodes/vertices and links/edges;
nodes are the portrayal of environment actors, while links are depicting relations
among the actors. In our scenario we model each aCAgent and aFTPAgent by a
separate node. Links are formed among nodes that have established a transport
contract. Hence, we obtain a social bipartite graph of cargo owners and transport
providers, where the social relationship is based on prior commercial agreements.
The broker and the broker registry are not included since they are only environ-
ment artefacts, acting as match makers, with no active role in the social relation-

12https://github.com/becheru/aicnet
13https://ipython.org/

37

ship formation and development. As a freight transport contract does not imply
a leadership/direction, we use undirected graphs in our modelling. Also, as mul-
tiple contracts can be established between the same freight transporter and cargo
owner, it is natural to augment our model with link weights.

As already mentioned, the broker is involved in two types of negotiation pro-
cesses: one with the cargo owner (left negotiation in Figure 1.3.1) and the other
with the freight transport providers (right negotiation in Fig. 1.3.1. Since the left
negotiation is one to one, we consider that social factors are less important here.
Nevertheless, we plan to explore the use of social information also in this case, as
future work. So, we will focus only on the right negotiation type, where the bro-
ker is involved in one tomany negotiations. Here the social characteristics of each
freight transporter will be explicitly considered to differentiate between them. We
are now considering possible social features for characterising freight transporters.

Measures of SocialWelfare

Centrality measures are indicators of the most important/influential nodes in a so-
cial graph. The PageRank ([173]
) is a highly utilised centrality measure in SNA
studies. It stands out as the underlying algorithmofGoogle’s search engine. The al-
gorithm for computing this measure takes into consideration the number of links
of a node (similarly withDegreemeasure) and their respective quality. Simply put,
it is important to have as many connections as possible with nodes that are also
highly connected.

In our scenario, a freight transporter with high PageRank established many
transport contracts with cargo owners that in their turn have established a sig-
nificant number of contracts with other highly successful transporters. From an
economic point of view, a highly rated transport provider according to PageRank
serves the transport needs of themost active cargo owners, i.e. those cargo owners
which are making most transport requests. Hence, such transport providers rep-
resent a crucial factor for the success of MAFTLS, as the revenue increases with
each established transport contract.

Another measure of centrality that we are considering in our work is Between-
ness, initially proposed by FreemanL.C. in [87]
and further developed byBrandes

38

U. in [38]
. It emphasises the nodes that act as bridges between graph communi-
ties, by representing the weak ties in a social graph, as described in [192]
.

Graph communities are establishedwhen a subset of nodes have a higher con-
nectivity between themselves rather than with the rest of the graph nodes. A de-
tailed description on how to discover such communities is given in [165]
. A possi-
ble cause for the presence of communities in our scenario would imply that some
cargo owners have mainly established transport contracts with the same trans-
port providers over time, due to some specificity of their cargo that can only be
satisfied by those transporters. For example, in the real world only a small per-
centage of freight transporters have oversized capabilities. Hence, cargo owners of
mainly oversized cargo would form a community with such transporters. A trans-
port provider with a high Betweenness coefficientmight have a wide range of trans-
port capabilities, as it can satisfy cargoowners that havewell established communi-
ties. At least we could say thatBetweenness can be used to highlight those transport
providers that are competitive across many transport domains; the more compet-
itive transporters, the better they are from an economic point of view.

Note that all themetrics are able to assign a quantifiablemeasure to each node
of the social graph, hence enabling their comparison by an appropriate ranking.

AICNET Strategies

Now that we have the means to determine the social welfare of each transport
provider, wemust establish the goal(s) of using them. We group one ormore goals
into strategies, for a better business alignment. The broker is the agent capable of
selecting and applying various strategies, according to its business and/or social
interests.

It is not possible to cover all the possible strategies, even in a larger paper.
Hence we will focus on few of them that we consider more relevant. We are aware
that a strategy can involve more SNAmetrics. However, in this work we consider
only strategies that can be at least partly satisfied by a single metric. The simul-
taneous intertwining of multiple metrics to adhere to a specific strategy will be
addressed in future works.

In subsection1.5.1wediscussed that the existenceof themonopolymightneg-

39

atively impact a market. Hence, being able to apply a strategy to hinder/disrupt
monopolies can be of great value for the broker. One such strategy may rely on
increasing competitiveness by providing an advantage to transport providers that
have this trait. Let us call this strategy Competitiveness Advantage (sCA). As al-
ready mentioned, such transport providers can be highlighted using the Between-
ness metrics. Hence, the transport provider with the highest Betweenness will be
awarded contracts with sCA. The second strategy, let us call it Page Rank (sPR),
will use PageRanrk centrality measure to identify nodes that represents potential
monopolies. The freight transporter with the lowest PageRank coefficient will be
selected as winner.

Having fixed those SNAmetrics thatwe intend toutilise as negotiation factors,
we now present some details of the winner selection in negotiation protocol (we
assume the reader familiarity with ICNET – a standard task allocation protocol in
MAS).

The simplest solution would be to directly (i.e. in one negotiation round) se-
lect based on the metric value. However, this approach would not imply really a
negotiation. Therefore, we decided to slightly update ICNET to better support the
use of our metrics. This is actually a natural development of our previous results
that discussed negotiation processes inMAFTLS ([141]
), as we can use those re-
sults as comparison benchmarks.

ICNET implies that the negotiation proceeds as a series of negotiation rounds
until one or more freight transport providers will agree with the broker’s offer or
the maximum number of iterations is reached (negotiation failure). During each
round the broker proposes a monetary value in exchange for the transport service
that the freight transporters can: accept – thus finishing the negotiation (negoti-
ation success), reject but continue to the next round and reject and withdraw of
the current negotiation. The accept is given when the broker bid is higher than
transporter bid ceiling, while the reject is given when the broker bid is lower than
the transporter bid floor. In between the bid ceiling and bid floor the transport
will reject the current bid, but it will proceed to the next round of negotiation. In
standard ICNET, if multiple transport providers accepted the offer in the current
round then the one with lowest price would win. In our variant, AICNET, the
accepting transport providers would be ranked based on a SNA metric and the

40

winner would be the highest/lowest ranked depending on the strategy used.

1.5.3 Experimental System Architecture

We now provide some of the details of our experimental system – ES. An exper-
iment is organised as a series of simulation rounds. Each simulation round deals
with solving of multiple transport requests. Each transport request can be satis-
fiedby anegotiationprocess that usually takes several negotiation iterations, with a
maximum threshold established. Thenegotiation protocol (ICNETorAICNET),
number of experiments, rounds and iterations are defined by the user at the start
of the experiment and they are fixed for the whole duration of the experiment. It
is noteworthy to mention that a series of simulation rounds can be continued by
another as the data is not lost between rounds, unless this is explicitly requested
by the user. These experiments produce and record results and information that
can be obtained by querying the ES’s statistical module.

The population of participant agents is automatically generated at the start of
each simulation round. Currently each cargo owner is only characterised by its id,
since cargo owners are not involved in the right side negotiation. The broker and
the transport providers have a more complex structure since they are endowed
with “personalities”. The details on the personalities have been introduced in Ta-
ble 1.4.1. The personalities influence the initial and reserve values (High Price or
Low Price) and the level of flexibility of the agents during a negotiation (Conser-
vative or Lenient). Transport providers change their personalities autonomously,
between consecutive transport requests, as they reach specific thresholds or ran-
domly. The broker personality is explicitly set by the user, while transporter per-
sonalities are set at the start of each experiment, by random selection from 4 avail-
able options.

As this experiment is focused only on the right-negotiation, the simulation of a
transport request issued by a cargo owner is simply reduced to: i) randomly select-
ing a cargo owner as transport request issuer, and ii) generating a random mone-
tary values between lj and ljLjLjLjLj that represents the estimated-transport-cost. In
MAFTLS, the broker-estimated-cost is computed by the broker based on the de-
tails of the transport request, to determine the broker initial bid. The broker bid

41

for each negotiation iteration is computed based on the previous bid value and the
broker personality.

During each negotiation iteration, the transporters receive the transport re-
quest from the broker, and consequently they compute their own transporter cost
estimation. In a realisticmarketwewouldexpect that the transporter-cost-estimation
of transporters is randomly distributed around the broker-estimated-cost. Hence,
we compute the transporter cost estimation for each transport provider using Gaus-
siandistribution, as follows. Themean is computedbyadding thebroker-estimated-
cost with a displacement (a parameter set by the user for each experiment). It mod-
els the estimation error of the transporters, for the broker-estimated-cost, as in a
real setting this value is private to the broker, so transporters do not know it ex-
actly. The standard deviation is given as displacement over deviation (user defined
scaling parameter).

Afterdetermining its private cost estimation, each transporterproceeds to com-
pute the bid ceiling and bid floor, based on its personality. Bid floor and bid ceiling
are updated in each negotiation iteration. Then the negotiation proceeds accord-
ing to the negotiation protocol, until termination is reached. If the negotiation
terminates with success then the social graph is updated by creating a new link be-
tween the cargo owner and the transport provider.

1.5.4 AICNET Experiments

Experimental Setup

ES has been developed as an object oriented program in Python which makes
it very easy to use and/or adapt. The user can easily interact with ES using two
classes: Environment and Statistics. The Environment classmakes the necessary ini-
tialisation and controls the execution of the negotiation processes. The Statistics
class is in charge of gathering data during the negotiation and presenting various
statistics to the user.

ES provides the user with a wide experimentation perspective, by suitable set-
ting of the various parameters. Because of the limited space, we focus here only on
experiments with the following settings of the simulation parameters: broker per-
sonality set to Low Price Lenient, 50 transport provider agents, 1000 cargo owner

42

agents, a thresholdofmaximum12 iterations per negotiation, displacement 10 and
deviation 10.

The experiments are focused on two broker strategies (Competitiveness Advan-
tage (sCA) and Page Rank (sPR), see Section 1.5.2), aiming to provide compelling
evidence that AICNET can satisfy the goal of each strategy. Sincewe are restricted
regarding the length of the paper, the details of using ES to run these experiments
are mentioned on the GitHub page of the tool. For each parameter setting, we
first run 1000 rounds of ICNET, to avoid the cold start problem for computing
graphmetrics, and thenwe run another 1000 rounds of AICNET (with ICNET in
parallel), to be able to draw conclusions about the effectiveness of AICNET and
compare it with ICNET. Concluding, after 2000 rounds we are able to compare
the results of running ICNET (2000 rounds) with those of running 1000 rounds
of ICNET followed by 1000 rounds of AICNET.

Results &Discussions

Table 1.5.1 presents some results obtained with ICNET and AICNET in the con-
text of the broker strategies. Regarding negotiation related metrics, we can ob-
serve one major advantage of AICNET: the number of iterations per negotiations
is slightly smaller, which translates in less waiting time for the cargo owner.

The gain per negotiation of the winning transporter is computed as the win-
ning price over the initial estimate of the broker. Hence, from a business perspec-
tive there are no or minor differences between ICNET and AICNET, which we
consider to be a major incentive for using AICNET. Some differences still arise,
albeit notmajor, whenwe take into account the personalities of the winning trans-
port providers. However, as stated before there is almost no impact on the ne-
gotiated monetary value. Our interpretation is that transporter providers that are
more conservative and give higher initial prices have better chances to participate
with success in AICNET than in ICNET, resulting in a slightly more inclusive ne-
gotiation protocol.

Regarding negotiation failures, both protocols act well. Although, as shown
in [141]
, when the implementation is done in a distributedMAS framework (e.g.
Jade), some failuresmayarisebecauseof communicationproblemsbetweenagents

43

distributedondifferentmachines. Basedonour obtained results, we speculate that
AICNET has a slight edge over ICNET.

Metric/Strategy sCA sPRICNET AICNET ICNET AICNET
Negotiation related metrics

Avg. No. of iterations per negotiation 3.186 2.084 2.268 1.633
Avg. Gain of the transporters 1.185 1.195 1.205 1.217

No. wins LOWPRICE LENIENT 1628 1544 1406 1292
No. wins LOWPRICE CONSERVATIVE 341 405 403 378

No. wins HIGH PRICE LENIENT 13 13 87 120
No. wins HIGH PRICE CONSERVATIVE 18 38 104 210

No. failed negotiations 0 0 0 0
Graph related metrics

AvgWeighted degree 3.810 3.808 3.810 3.808
Avg path length 3.780 3.602 3.771 3.786

Diameter 6 6 6 6
No. communities 155 156 158 160

Table 1.5.1: AICNET Results of negotiation and graph related metrics

Analysing the graph related metrics for sPR, they might superficially suggest
that they only display minor differences, and thus supporting the idea that both
graphs are in fact almost identical. However, this is not true, as clearly shown in
Figure 1.5.2. We can observe on that figure that the graph produced using AIC-
NET is slightly more connected at the graph periphery, thus supporting the inclu-
sion supposition. Amajor difference canbe seenby looking at thenodes represent-
ing the transport providers (shown in purple). With ICNET, the diameter of the
nodes variesmore thanwithAICNET.Note that the diameters are proportional to
the PageRank coefficient. Hence, we could argue that AICNET with sPR has suc-
cessfully hindered the rise of monopolies. This statement is further supported by
the plots in Figure 1.5.1. Both the number of wins and the PageRank coefficients
are flatten out in AICNET.Hence sPR is proven to be highly effective in hindering
the rise of monopolies, while having no negative impact on the monetary values
and other relevant metrics.

We obtained rather similar values of graph relatedmetrics with sCA. However,

44

Figure 1.5.1: AICNET Plots of results obtained by applying sPR. (left side)
PageRank coefficient for each transporter, (right side) the total number of

wins per each transporter.

Figure 1.5.2: Plots of social graphs results obtained by applying ICNET (left
side) and AICNET with sPR (RIGHT SIDE). Green nodes represent cargo

owners while purple nodes represent transport providers. The diameter of the
nodes is proportional to their PageRank coefficient. For plotting we used

ForceAtlas 2 algorithm included in Gephi

as shown in Figure 1.5.4, we can see observe different results than with sPR. The
ICNET graph is by farmore connected and there is clear evidence in the AICNET
graph that at least two monopolies have risen, purple node at the top and the one
at the right bottom part. Moreover, the distribution of the transport provider’s
wins and their associated PageRank coefficient are similar to power-law distribu-
tions, see Figure 1.5.3. Hence, this strategy does not hinder monopolies, rather it

45

Figure 1.5.3: AICNET Plots of results obtained by applying sCA. (left side)
PageRank coefficient for each transporter, (right side) the total number of

wins per each transporter.

Figure 1.5.4: Plots of social graphs results obtained by applying ICNET (left
side) and AICNET with sCA (RIGHT SIDE). Green nodes represent cargo

owners while purple nodes represent transport providers. The diameter of the
nodes is proportional to their respective PageRank coefficient. For plotting we

used ForceAtlas 2 algorithm included in Gephi.

encourages their rise.
Based on our results we can conclude that sPR is a good strategy for hindering

monopolies, while on the contrary, sCA is facilitating them.

46

1.6 Conclusions & FutureWork

Throughout this chapterwe have discussed the semanticmodelling of information
relevant to freight transportation and proposed communication and interactions
means among the agents involved. For this purposes several ontologies have been
developed and tested based on MAFTLS usage scenarios. Moreover, we have es-
tablished through experiments that state of the art negotiation protocols, like IC-
NET, can be used with success with MAFTLS in order to mitigate conflicts. Nev-
ertheless, we introduced a novel negotiation protocol based on CNA methods,
which was proven capable to implement advanced negotiation scenarios. Hence,
we conclude that CNAmethods and techniques have been introduce with success
in the field of freight transport.

Although the present work has reached a relative maturity, there is still a lot
of ground to research. One direction is especially promising, the introduction of
various business strategies in AICNET.

47

48

I do not fear computers. I fear the lack of them.

Isaac Asimov

2

In the early days of

http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

emphasised that informa-
tion and communication technologies (ICT)will shape
Number of identical words : 6
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

The author claimed that a new type of tourism was emerging driven by “new
Number of identical words : 17
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 con-
sumers, new technologies, newproductionpractices, newmanagement techniques
and changes in the industry frame condition”. According to Carter & Bédard
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

by destinations and business. By the year 2008, Buhalis & Law

provided evidence that “the technological revolution experienced through the

velopment of internet has changed dramatically
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

organisations”. Moreover, the authors emphasised that ICT technologies have em-
powered a new type of traveller that is “seeking exceptional value for money and
time” and is “keener to pursue their own preferences and schedule”. An example
of a technological empowered accommodation business is Airbnb
Number of identical words : 34
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

the largest hotel chain in the world without actually owning a hotel. This type of
business has pushed previous industry leaders, e.g. Marriott, to invest heavily in
ICT solutions.
Number of identical words : 33
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

touristic destinations, such as the city of Barcelona in Spain, see
Number of identical words : 21
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

work has shown that Airbnb’s accommodation created a clear
Number of identical words : 11

sure in the city. Furthermore, the results “suggest that Airbnb benefits in greater
measure than hotels from proximity of the most visited places in the city”.

2.1.2 Natural language processing

Texts expressed
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

of touristic services present informationonSmartTourismportals. These texts de-
scribe users’ opinions and/ or experiences on various touristic entities. Hence, a
need arises to
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 meth-
ods.

NLP is an applied computing field interested in the automated computational
analysis of natural language texts
Number of identical words : 16
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 (ManningC.D.&SchützeH. in [145]
). Jackson,
P. & Moulinier I. in [118]
present a survey of the use of NLP for online
Number of identical words : 10
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 applica-
tions. Natural language texts are composed of sentences, hence various linguistic
theories were proposed along the ages to understand natural language sentences.
They all agree that the foundation of sentence structure relies on identifying and
Number of identical words : 34
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
analysing the various relations among words (subject, complement),
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 see Hristea
F. T. in [115]
. The most common NLP approach of representing these relations
is the dependency graph, encapsulating both syntactic and semantic features.
Number of identical words : 19
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 De-
pendency parsers are used to construct dependency graphs, based on the
Number of identical words : 10
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 theoret-

52

ical foundations of dependency grammars, see Kübler S. et al.
Number of identical words : 9
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 in [130]
. Hence,
graphs represent a natural approach to capture and process connections between
words in
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 natural language texts. They were proven to be efficient for lexical
Number of identical words : 11
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ac-
quisition by Widdows D. & Dorow B.
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 [229]
, sentence parsing by Radev D. R. &
Mihalcea R.
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 [185]
, in word sense disambiguation Navigli R. & Lapata M.
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 [161]
,
or text summarising byMihalcea, R. [154]
.

A series of research papers supports the utility of NLP within the context of
Smart Tourism. Yuan. H et al.
Number of identical words : 20
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

by determining co-occurrences of travel destinations extracted from texts posted
on travel blogs, aiming to provide tourists with better travel scheduling. Through

from online expressed touristic reviews. Hence, travellers could be informed
Number of identical words : 19

front on the quality of the reviews to further simplify their decision making
Number of identical words : 12

cess.

In this study, we rely on NLP methods such as sentence segmentation,
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 to-
kenization, Part-Of-Speech tagging (POS) and lemmatization. More details of
these methods are presented in
Number of identical words : 15
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 [202]
. For bench-marking regarding the accuracy
of our proposed approaches, we employ
Number of identical words : 9
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 standardmeasures, like for example Term
Frequency Inverse Document Frequency (tf-idf ), introduced in
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 [206]
, and ini-
tially proposed in the field of information retrieval.
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

2.1.3 CNA in Smart Tourism

CNAwas also used in the context of Smart Tourism. Some of the works, e.g.,
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 Ben-
dle L. J. & Patterson I. [30]
, Miguéns J. I. L. &Mendes J. F. F.

and Presenza

http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

constructed from touristic oriented sources. Results confirm the complex nature
Number of identical words : 17
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

3https://www.tripadvisor.com/

53

of the networks as they have a power-law degree distribution. From a business

see the study on the Elba region in Italy by Baggio R. & Cooper C.

and

and [220]

ing the value of the use of
Number of identical words : 6
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

point of view. Hence, our study will try to provide knowledge that will ultimately
be in the benefit of the tourists.

2.1.4 Graph databases

“Graph databases leverage complex and dynamic relations in highly connected
data to generate insight”, and “they represent the best way to represent and query
Number of identical words : 26
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

54

connected data” as stated by Robinson I.
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 in [187]
. Since our work is centred on
discovering textual relations from reviews and touristic social relations, the choice
of using graph databases comes natural. Moreover, this type of database has the
advantage of being readily available for any join-like navigation operation, that we
will heavily rely on in discovering information, as opposed to SQL and NoSQL
database systems. As tool, we used Neo4j
Number of identical words : 60
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 4, as it is an ACID
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 compliant transac-
tional database with native graph storage and processing. Nevertheless, Neo4j
has also been
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 proposed in other Smart Tourism research papers. For example,
Karakostas, B. et al.
Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 [124]
have employed Neo4j to develop a knowledge-based
system for travel mode recommendation, while Jinyan, C. et al.
Number of identical words : 20
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 [122]
explored
tourist’s observations for monitoring environmental, with the help of Neo4j.
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

2.2 Experimental scenarios

2.2.1 Data Source

As data source we use the information available on Romanian website
Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 AmFostA-
colo ( English translation is “I have been there”), which is one of the most
Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 popu-
lar tourist opinion sharing online portals in Romania. This portal provides semi-
structured data oriented on post-visit tourist reviews about a large variety of
Number of identical words : 24
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 loca-
tions covering specific aspects of accommodation as well as general impressions
about touristic sights. From a geographical point of view, tourist attractions
Number of identical words : 21
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 de-
picted on the website mainly cover Romania and Europe with less data for other
continents. This is due to the visitation habits and financial restrictions of native
Romanian tourists. The data is hierarchically structured according to the country,
region, section and geographical place. For example, Corte Zeuli B&B
Number of identical words : 48
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 is a place
under the country Italy, region Puglia and section Bari.

A potential user of the portal can interact with other users in two ways. First,
the user can ask questions and provide answers to other questions. This
Number of identical words : 39
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 function-
ality is especially useful for planning purposes, before travelling to a specific
Number of identical words : 11
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 loca-
tion for which enough suitable survey information is not available. Secondly, users
can post tourist impressions related to certain places. Hence, for each place,
Number of identical words : 23
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 amul-

4https://neonjj.com/

55

titude of impressions posted by various users is available. Moreover, impressions
can be commented using echoes issued by other users, with the goal either of
Number of identical words : 24
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 pre-
senting further clarifications or of requesting additional information. Although
echoes and questions might apparently share similar functionalities, echoes can
only exist in the presence of an impression, whereas questions can be posted
Number of identical words : 31
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 unre-
lated to any impression. For a better understanding of the structure of the portal,
please consult Figure
Number of identical words : 16
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 2.2.1. The portal automatically associates each user with a
rank computed based on the user portfolio and feedback provided on the website,
Number of identical words : 21
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
including facts like: impressions, uploaded photos, posts, and answers.

Figure
Number of identical words : 10
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

2.2.2 Question-answering scenarios

Our first scenario focuses on the analysis of
Number of identical words : 11
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 theAmFostAcolo users’ social network
that emerges from using the question-answering functionality. We focus on this
functionality for inferring the social network describing users’ interaction, as
Number of identical words : 25
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ap-
parently more users have taken advantage of it rather than the impression-echoing
functionality, i.e. 53172 questions versus 2541 impressions. This difference can
be explained as follows. We claim that using the question-answering
Number of identical words : 34
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 functional-
ity requires less effort, i.e. reading and understanding of shorter texts, than longer
Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

56

impressions. Also, it is assumed that a user posting an impression on a touristic
attraction has already visited it, although the portal does not enforce any kind of
verification. Hence, users are limited in posting impressions versus posting
Number of identical words : 38
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ques-
tions. Apart from analysing the resulting social network, we also used Neo4j to
link users to questions and answers, with the purpose of developing a method for
digesting users’ interests.
Number of identical words : 28
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

Thefirst stepwas to extract the data from the portal
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 usingweb scrapping, more
specifically by applying Java’s jsoup
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 HTML parsing library5. A series of XML files
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
were obtained, one for each user, with the XML schema detailed in Figure
Number of identical words : 11
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 2.2.2.
For experimental purposes andeaseofmanipulation, aMySQL6 databasewaspop-
ulated with the data present in the XML files (see Figure
Number of identical words : 10
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 2.2.3 for the relational
schema). Thereafter, we could count 54352 users out of which 3132 have asked at
least a question and 7831 that gave at least an answer. In total 8936 (active) users
have been using the question-answering functionality. Also, we counted 53172
questions and 53150 answers. If we take into consideration only the users that
Number of identical words : 57
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ac-
tually posted questions, we get an average of 16.1 questions such user, respectively
those that posted answers, we get an average of 6.7 answers per user. Furthermore,
we exported the database into CSV
Number of identical words : 32
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 files, as an intermediary step for importing the
data
Number of identical words : 9
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 intoNeo4j. Also, by usingMySQLwe could easily import the data
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

network analysis tool. For a better understanding of the entire extraction and pre-
processing step, please consult the graphical representation shown in Figure
Number of identical words : 23
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

Graph Database Experiments

Graph data models consist of nodes and arcs, where nodes represent entities and
arcs capture binary relations between entities. Both nodes and arcs can be
Number of identical words : 28
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 en-
riched with attributes, e.g. if a node represents a user we can attach the age
Number of identical words : 15
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 at-
tribute. In this scenario, we model three types of entities: user, answer and
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ques-
tion. We considered three relations in our model. Relation r : ASK connects a
user (qUser) and a question. Relation r:HAS links a question and an answer.
Number of identical words : 26
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 Rela-
tion r : GIVENBY is defined between an answer and a user providing that answer.
You can inspect the corresponding Neo4j data model in Figure
Number of identical words : 23
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 2.2.5. 2.2.5. For

5https://jsoup.org/
6https://www.mysql.com/

57

querying purposes, we employedCypher, the native querying language for Neo4j.
McKnight W.
Number of identical words : 10
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 provides more details on Cypher
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 in [148]
.

With thehelpofAmFostAcolo’s question-answeringdata available inNeo4j for-
mat, wewere able to identify the interests of a user,
Number of identical words : 8
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 anoperationknownasuser pro-
filing. Consider the following scenario: users A, B, and C are a group friends who
decided that they should spend their next vacation together. Nevertheless, each
user has its particularities and interests and they
Number of identical words : 33
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 allwould like to go to adestination
that pleases each of them, a taunting task for the travel agency that they contacted.
Having access to their previous question-answering data, the travel company can
develop a profile for each of them by consistently combining their interests in
Number of identical words : 40
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 or-
der to provide them better recommendations.
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

To further prove the utility of using Neo4j with the data gathered from the
touristic portal consider the following scenario. User A is looking for users that
have similar interest, aiming to discover potential new (for user A) touristic
Number of identical words : 41
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 loca-
tions to visit. Hence, we could compute similarity among users taking in
Number of identical words : 11
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 consider-
ation the percentage of questions answered, questions posted by user A, by other
users. For example, if user A posted 10 questions out of which 3 were answered
by user B and 5 by user C.Then, user A has a similarity of
Number of identical words : 42
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 NjLj% to user B and ǍLj%
to user C. In order to answer a user’s question another user has to visit the place X
on the portal, where the question was addressed. Hence, we can deduce that both
users have an interest in place X, from which we deduce the similarity. This
Number of identical words : 47
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 sce-
nario can be thought as recommender system for users with similar interests. As
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
wewill further prove, throughNeo4jwe caneasily build this recommender system.

CNA scenarios

For this part of the study, our entities of interest are the users,
Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 representedbynodes
of the social graph. We created arcs as follows: an arc connects source
Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 node A to
destination node B if node B posted a question upon which node A answered; A
is the source node and B the target node. We have considered only the socially
engaged users, i.e. users that posted at least one question or one answer. Thus,
Number of identical words : 48
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

58

Figure 2.2.2: XML schema capturing user interaction data.

questions and answers.

we created a social network based on the question-answering functionality of the
website.

http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

self-looping arcs, as they represent answers

http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

those users that answered only to their own questions. Consequently, we reduced
our network to 8017 nodes and 25666 arcs. Moreover, we annotated nodes and
Number of identical words : 25
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

follow three directions:

• Inspect the topological aspects of the network, in order to understand how
users
Number of identical words : 26
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

• Provide a temporal analysis, in order to understand the evolution of the
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

cial network.

• Determine inner communities of users and their traits, to identify trends
and similitudes among users

We focused on the following questions that we consider of high interest:

1. Is our network a complex network and if so what type of complex network?
What are the traits of the complex network type?

2. Are there present any sociological phenomena and if
Number of identical words : 61
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 sowhat are their traits?

3. Is the network resilient?

4. How did the network evolve over time?

5. Is the network expanding or contracting?

6. Is there any evidence that a specific positive or negative review had or may
have significant influence on the community?

7. Can we determine inner-communities and their specific traits?
Number of identical words : 54
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

2.2.3 Impression-echoing scenarios

This experimental scenario follows the AmFostAcolo’s impression-echoing
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 func-
tionality. Using the web scrapping technology,
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 wewere able to collect impressions
posted by
Number of identical words : 6
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ljLjǐǍ users (njNJNjmales and ǎǎNJ females), totalling a number of NJǍNJlj im-
pressions, dispersed over:

• njǍ countries

• ljǎlj regions among which 16 country sub-regions and
Number of identical words : 8
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

• ǍNJǑ sections among which njǐǑ localities (cities, town or villages)
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

• ljnjNJLj tourist locations among which:

61

– ǍNjnj accommodation units (cottages, pensions, hotels, houses or
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 vil-
las)

– ǐǐǎ sections, i.e. representing impressions about a tourist location

In our current scenario, the goal is to define new text analytics methods for
Number of identical words : 23
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
analysing tourist impressions/reviews based on NLP and
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 CNA methods, aiming
to better capture users’ touristic interests. The proposed method is fully
Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 unsu-
pervised, see Figure 2.2.6 for a graphical representation, and proceeds as follows.
For each review, we captured the title, text and metadata. The title and the text
were parsed through a chain of
Number of identical words : 29
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 NLPmethods that include: tokenization, Part-Of-
Speech tagging and lemmatization. Hence, the boundaries of each sentence were
marked and the part of speech and lemma were attached to each word, in order to
unify the representation of all occurrences of the same lexical unit. Next, the
Number of identical words : 45
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 re-
view title and content were fully annotated with dependency relations, using the
Romanian Dependency Parser
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 7. A graph/complex network (undirected graph) is
resulted, nodes representing lemmas of words and links for dependencies, while
keeping the dependency names as link attributes. We used Syntactic filters to
Number of identical words : 30
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 re-
move nodes out of the graph, only keeping nodes with meaningful information.
For example, we could consider only nouns and verbs as being meaningful, as
Number of identical words : 24
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 car-
rying relevant semantic information. Hence, we could just keep nodes that
Number of identical words : 10
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 repre-
sent nouns and verbs and their respective links.

For this experiment, we decided to consider only the words that have stable
lexical meanings, i.e. nouns, verbs, adjectives and adverbs. We ignored function
words, i.e. prepositions, articles and pronoun, as they only have syntactic
Number of identical words : 44
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 func-
tions, i.e. theydonot convey valuable information for our analysis. Next, we fusion
the different occurrences of the
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 sameword in a unique node and
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 thenwe gather all
relations in which each occurrence was involved. The syntactic filtering and
Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 uni-
fication steps of different occurrences reduced the size of the complex network,
making its computational analysis easier, often resulting in a sparse graph/
Number of identical words : 22
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 com-
plex network. Thismethod of representing text from reviews/impressions entirely
covers all the dependencies, i.e. there was no loss of valuable information. Our
analysis
Number of identical words : 22
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 forked into two directions: text summarization using keyword extraction
Number of identical words : 9
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

7http://nlptools.infoiasi.ro/WebFdgRo/

62

via PageRank algorithm and words’ cohesion checking.
The first direction assumes the review summarization by identifying relevant

words as keywords. We achieved this by computing two different NS metrics for
Number of identical words : 30
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
eachnode: PageRank coefficient andDegree, and then ranking the nodes according
to
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 themetric used. According toPageRankmetric, aword is a keyword if it is highly
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
linkedwithwords that are alsohighly linkedwithotherwords. According toDegree
metric, a word is considered a keyword if is
Number of identical words : 9
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 linkedwithmany other words, with no
regards on the others linkage. In order to evaluate the proposed keyword
Number of identical words : 16
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 identi-
fication methods, we investigate the occurrences of keywords among title words
and metadata. The review metadata consists of location information, i.e. country,
region, section, and location name.
Number of identical words : 27
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 Themetadatawas also included in this analysis
since no words in the title were present in the review’s text for
Number of identical words : 19
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ǏǍ% of the reviews.
This evaluation assumes that discovered keywords and words in the title represent
the summary of the review. Moreover, we also used a third method based on the
standard tf-idf from information retrieval, to compute the keywords capturing the
semantics of each review. We computed the term frequency for each separate
Number of identical words : 54
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 re-
view, while the inverse document frequency was computed for the entire corpus
of review texts. We introduced this third method in order to benchmark our
Number of identical words : 24
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 pro-
posed methods versus a standard and widely used keyword extraction method.

The second direction tries to determine if the words defining each review have
high cohesion. This would imply that the expressed ideas are tightly connected.
This metric could be used to judge if the reviews were not randomly generated,
and thus increasing the relevance of our experimental results. We assume that
Number of identical words : 56
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 tex-
tual cohesion is present in texts if the small-world phenomenon is observed in the
corresponding graph representations of those texts. This in turn is depicted by
evaluating the following
Number of identical words : 29
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 CNAmetrics: Average Clustering Coefficient, Average Path
Length
Number of identical words : 6
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 andDiameter. Moreover, we would expect this to correlate positively with
the presence of a giant component in the graph that represents the text.
Number of identical words : 22
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

63

Figure 2.2.6: Impression-echoing experiments pipeline.

2.3 Results & Discussions

Following the introduction of the experimental details, we are now discussing the
results obtained. We have aligned the presentation of the results with the
Number of identical words : 25
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 descrip-
tion of each experiment.

2.3.1 OnQuestion- Answer Scenarios

Graph Database Experiments
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

Theavailability ofAmFostAcolo’s question-answering data inNeo 4j format helps in
identifying the interests of each user (profiling). As for the first scenario regarding
graph databases, a travel agency can use Cypher extract the questions and answers
of a given user respectively, as depicted
Number of identical words : 38
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 in Listing 2.1.

1 MATCH (uq : User )О[Ask]О>(q : Que s t i on s )
2 WHERE uq . u s e r I d = ” 15 ”
3 RETURN uq , q
4 MATCH (uq : User )О[ASK]О>(q : Que s t i on s ) )О[h :HAVE]О>

64

5 ( a : Answers ) О [ r :GIVEN_BY] О> [ ua :USER]
6 WHERE ua . u s e r I d = ” 15 ”
7 RETURN ua , a , q

Listing 2.1: Cypher User profiling query.

Thesecond graph database scenario, regarding the recommendation of similar
users, can be fulfilled by using the Cypher query language to determine the sub-
graph of users that gave answers to questions asked by a certain user, as
Number of identical words : 36
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 in Listing
2.2.

1 MATCH (uq : User )О[Ask]О>(q : Que s t i on s )О[h :HAVE]О>
2 ( a : Answers ) О [ r :GIVEN_BY] О> [ ua :USER]
3 WHERE uq . u s e r I d = ” 15 ”
4 RETURN uq , q , a , ua
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

Listing 2.2: Cypher user recommandation query.

Weacknowledge the fact thatmanymore scenarios can be envisioned and that
the data model can be extended. However, we claim that these experiments have
proven the usefulness of graph databases in the context of Smart Tourism.
Number of identical words : 31
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

CNA Experiments

We start our network science experiments by focusing on the topological aspects
supported by various NS metrics. The Diameter metric represents the size of the
longest path connecting two nodes of the graph, with a computed value of 16 for
a graph of
Number of identical words : 44
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 NJǍǎǎǎ we can argue that observed value is quite low. Furthermore, the
Average Path Length is
Number of identical words : 15
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 Ǎ:LjnjNJ which we consider to be low for our graph. Both the
Diameter and the Average Path Length are predictors of the small world social
Number of identical words : 24
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 phe-
nomenon, which we argue to be present in our network due to the relative small
values of the metrics in question, see
Number of identical words : 21
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 paper [215]
. The implications of the small
world presence indicate a tighten community of users, where information travels
fast. Hence, we can argue that either positive or negative information on a
Number of identical words : 29
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 touris-
tic attraction has a significant influence on the community, as it can spread fast
and easily from user to user, thus answering question six. Furthermore, additional
empirical tests on
Number of identical words : 28
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 thediffusionof information strengthen the evidenceon thepres-
ence of the small world phenomenon. In the diffusion experiments, we chose as
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

65

sources the nodes at the periphery of the network, with a diffusion loss of
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ǏLj%
at each step, assuming that only the
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 neighbours and neighbours of neighbours of
the source node could further broadcast. The results have shown that a significant
or even large majority of the nodes will receive some information. Figure
Number of identical words : 26
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 2.3.1
presents a graphical exemplification of the results of the diffusion experiment.
Number of identical words : 11
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

nodes’ diameters are proportional to their PageRank coefficient. The
Number of identical words : 17
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 colour of
the nodes depicts if information through the diffusion experiment has reached
them (red) or not (grey).
Number of identical words : 17
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

in Gephi.

TheAverageDegreehas a valueofNj:NJLjlj, while theAverageWeightedDegreehas a
value of Ǎ:ǐǐlj. Thismeans that in average a user responds to
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ǎ questions addressed

66

by Nj other users. Hence, the average social activity is low, which also corroborates
with the value of
Number of identical words : 16
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 theAverage Clustering Coefficient of Lj:LjljǍ. On computing the dis-
tribution of the nodes’ degree, we observed that the distribution has scale-free type.
This implies that few users are very active (acting as hubs) while the
Number of identical words : 26
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 greatmajority
are not, which is in line with the values obtained for Degree and Average Weighted
Degree metrics. Moreover, this distribution occurs frequently in the Internet, as
well as in the natural world, as stated in
Number of identical words : 35
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 [1]
and other Smart Tourism complex
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 net-
works as mentioned by Baggio, R.
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 [13]
. According to the statistical mechanics of
scale-free networks studied by
Number of identical words : 11
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 Barabási A. L. et al. in [18]
, this type of networks
emerges if both growth and preferential attachment social phenomena are present.
Hence, we found evidence that the social network is growing, answering question
5.
Number of identical words : 28
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 NewmanM. E. defined the preferential attachment phenomenon
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 in [163]
as a
set of processes in which some quantity, quality, or typically some form of wealth
or credit is distributed among a number of individuals or objects according to how
much they already have, so those who are already wealthy will receive more than
those who are not. This phenomenon is also known as rich get richer. In our
Number of identical words : 59
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 con-
text this implies that posts from a very active user
Number of identical words : 9
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ( responded to many questions)
weighs more (as is more trusted) than an answer from a typical user. The plot
presented in Figure
Number of identical words : 22
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 2.3.2 shows that the nodes’ degree follows a scale-free
Number of identical words : 9
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 distri-
bution. These results presented on the sociological phenomena provide answers
to questions 2 and 4.
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

According toFigure 2.3.1, the visual perception suggests that this network is of
the type core-periphery, as described
Number of identical words : 15
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 by Hojman D. A. & Szeidl A.
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 in [110]
. This
type of network has a central conglomerate of very well connected (core) nodes,
while the outer parts of the network (periphery) are more scattered. To prove the
validity of this empirical observation we need to extract the core and
Number of identical words : 40
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 analyse its
connectivity. Since the core should be the higher connected part of the graph, we
could extract it by removing the nodes with a degree less than
Number of identical words : 27
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 NjLj (ljLj times the
average) and their respective links. Hence, a graph of
Number of identical words : 11
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 NjLjLj nodes (Nj:Ǐnj% of the to-
tal) and NJLjǐLj (ǐ:Ǐlj% of the total links) was obtained (core graph). Then, we
Number of identical words : 10
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 com-
puted the followingCNAmetrics and compared the results with those attained for
the entire network. Unsurprisingly, the results indicate a higher connectivity of the
Number of identical words : 20
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

67

network.

http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

by the users in the core. The Diameter value is

 Ǒ versus ljǎ and the Average Path

Number of identical words : 7

Number of identical words : 13

Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 Lj:Ljǎǐ versus Lj:LjljǍ. To become part
of the core members, one has to be active, hence in a sense we can argue that the
social network is meritocratic and can be trusted. The core plays the role of a
Number of identical words : 36
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 dif-
fusion enhancer, which is consistent with the rest of our findings. Based on the
above findings, we can sustain that the entire network is of core-periphery type. A
relevant trait for this type of complex network is its resilience to change. This
Number of identical words : 42
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 im-
plies that the giant component of the network will be divided only in the case of a
Number of identical words : 16
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

68

catastrophic event, e.g. the loss of a significant part of
Number of identical words : 11
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 themost active users. Hence,
we consider answered both question 1 and 3.

Next, we focus our topological analysis on the inner communities that rise
in the social network (further called communities), thus lowering the granularity
level of the network. For the detection of these communities, we used
Number of identical words : 46
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 theMod-
ularity algorithm devised by Blondel, V. D et al.
Number of identical words : 8
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 in [32]
. First we compute the
Modularity coefficient which lies in the range of
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 [ОLj:Ǎ; lj]. A positive value of the
coefficient suggests that the number of links within groups exceeds the number
expected on the basis of chance, i.e. randomly assigned links. For our network,
the value of
Number of identical words : 34
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 theModularity coefficient is Lj:njǐ. This supports the presence of social
communities. The number of detected communities is
Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ljnjǎ. However, this large
number is biased by the presence of small and/or peripheral communities. Hence,
we considered only the communities that are part of the graph’s giant component.
There are 25 such communities. In order to analyse the interactions among these
communities, we constructed a directed graph of communities (let’s call it Gco)
as follows. Nodes of the same community fused into a single node, the
Number of identical words : 69
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 commu-
nity node. Links amongmembers of the samecommunity disappeared, while links
amongmembers of different communities fused into single links among the
Number of identical words : 9
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 repre-
sentative community nodes’ of each user. Based on the initial data from the portal
we added directionality to the links, such that the source node is the community
node representing the user answering the question and the target is the node
Number of identical words : 40
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 rep-
resenting the community of the user that posted the question. Upon computing
the Average Degree on the Gco we got a value of
Number of identical words : 22
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 njǏ:NJ, see Figure 2.3.3 for more
details. We computed the Degree as the sum of the In-Degree and the Out-Degree;
since we have
Number of identical words : 21
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 NJǍ nodes, the maximum value for In-Degree and Out-Degree is
Number of identical words : 11
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 NJnj.
Thus, the maximum value for Degree is
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 njǐ. This implies that users from different
communities do interact, which further strengthens the finding that information
can travel fast and with ease. Figure
Number of identical words : 23
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 2.3.4 presents the graph of communities.
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

Since wewere able to detect inner-communities in our network, we claim that
we have partially answered question 7. To consider this question fully answered,
we still have to determine and point out touristic traits that are specific for each
Number of identical words : 38
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

69

Figure 2.3.3: AmFostAcolo’s Degree distribution for nodes in the graph of
communities (Gco).
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

Figure 2.3.4: AmFostAcolo’s community graph. Each node represents a
community; nodes are distinguished by their unique color. The diameter of

each node is proportional to its PageRank coefficient.
Number of identical words : 27
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

community. In this endeavour, we also used the Modularity algorithm to detect
the communities, but we did not restrict its application only to those
Number of identical words : 24
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 communi-
ties that are part of the network’s giant component. In order to capture only the
relevant communities, we filtered out those with less than
Number of identical words : 24
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ljLj users. We propose
two approaches for discovering traits based on the available data, captured from
the portal. Concerning users’ metadata, we can compute the average scores per
Number of identical words : 27
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

70

community for the following: sex, age, average score given per touristic entity,
number of sentences written and rank (computed by the portal). If these
Number of identical words : 24
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 aver-
ages vary from community to community, then we can assume that they represent
specific traits of each community. Since we have obtained the texts for questions
and answers for each user, we propose to aggregate these texts per each
Number of identical words : 38
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 commu-
nity and then determine textual traits for each resulting text. First we parsed each
users’ questions and answers using the Part-of-Speech tagger for Romanian
Number of identical words : 25
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 lan-
guage described in [114]
, thus obtaining a set of tokens together with their
Number of identical words : 9
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 occur-
rence frequency. Next, we aggregated the tokens for each community of users and
computed their community frequency. We filtered tokens to keep only those
Number of identical words : 23
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 to-
kens representingnouns, verbs and adjectives, as the rest of the tokens possess only
syntactic information that is not relevant for our purpose. Moreover, we ranked
decreasingly by their occurrence frequency the nouns, verbs and adjectives
Number of identical words : 33
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 and
considered the top 10 most frequent as candidates for capturing touristic traits.
Hence, for each community we obtained
Number of identical words : 19
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 Nj lists of the ljLjmost frequent tokens for
the parts of speech considered.
Number of identical words : 8
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

Regarding the metadata traits, we were able to reach some results. The users’
age varies between
Number of identical words : 16
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 NjLj and Njǎ years old and the users’ rank varies between
Number of identical words : 8
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 Nj:ǐ to
Ǎ:nj (on a scale from Lj to ljNJ), for each community. Due to their low variance, these
parameters cannot be considered as representing specific traits, while the users are
apparently uniformly distributed. Unfortunately, the results obtained for the other
metadata (sex, average score given per touristic entity and number of sentences
written) were not significant, so this aspect needs to be further examined in future
works. However, the communities have a larger variance for noun and verb textual
tokens. Hence, we argue that the
Number of identical words : 76
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 topmost frequent nouns and verbs can be seen as
specific touristic traits for each community. As a fact, we observed that the verb to
eat is the only frequently used verb for the vast majority of communities. Hence,
we can argue that eating is considered a key activity regardless of tourists various
interests. Despite having also a large variance, the
Number of identical words : 59
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 largemajority of adjectives refer
tomonetary values, which do not provide useful information by themselves. Here
the context plays a key role that we did not properly consider in this experiment.
Hence, we claim that further studies should consider nouns and verbs as specific
traits for each community, while adjectives should be captured
Number of identical words : 47
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 togetherwith some

71

context information.
Our topological study could continue by further lowering the granularity of

the analysis towards nodes. However, we left this kind of deeper investigation as
future work. Nevertheless, we identified two directions of interest. The first one
should focus on the nodes importance in the social
Number of identical words : 47
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 network. This can be deter-
mined using the PageRank algorithm or using the Betwenness metric to highlight
the users that
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 play a major role in the
Number of identical words : 6
https://muse.jhu.edu/book/32697
 spread of information. Rewarding (given
by the portal) the users of great social
Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 importancemay represent the necessary in-
centive for those users to further continue and/or improve their presence on the
portal. Thus, the portal, the users in question and the other users will see the
Number of identical words : 28
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 bene-
fits of a more “social” network. Another direction involves using the geographical
metadata for the users and questions, to determine touristic trends of visitation. It
is possible to create a complex network where nodes represent locations and links
represent interest in locations that can be further analysed as described in
Number of identical words : 49
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 [153]
.

As initially planned, we also conducted a temporal analysis of the social
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 net-
work. In order to fulfil the analysis, we retrieved fromAmFostAcolo portal the date
of each question and answer posting. As methodology, we considered capturing
a yearly snapshot, from 2010 to 2015 on the 1st of January of each year. Previous
data were also available, but the network was of negligible size. As Figure
Number of identical words : 44
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 2.3.5
shows, the network continuously grew in size and developed its shape, from the
core to the periphery (like a tree). The growth process appears to be cyclical as
follows:

1. Expansion step. It consists in attracting new users in the network. Observe
the years 2010 and 2014.

2. Development step. It consists in new links creation among the current users
with less attraction of new users. Observe the years 2011, 2012, 2013 and
2015.

3. Return to step 1.

Hence, the cycle appears to span
Number of identical words : 85
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 anumber of years, with the first year being the
expansion step, while the following
Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 Nj years are devoted to the development step.
However, we believe that this temporal
Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 analysismust be repeated for the following
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

72

years (2016 and afterwards) for strengthening this analysis. Nevertheless, we have
yet again brought evidence that the social network is expanding, thus providing an
answer to question 5.
Number of identical words : 28
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

Figure 2.3.5: AmFostAcolo’s time lapse of the social network as captured of
the 1st of January of each year.

http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
