Impression-echoing scenarios

Table 2.3.1 shows a summary of the results for the keyword extraction process.
Before commenting on the results, we should mention that just for
Number of identical words : 22
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ǏNJNj reviews
(outofNJǍNJlj)wecouldfinda commonword in the title and in the
Number of identical words : 6
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 text of the review,
while considering nouns, adjectives, adverbs, and verbs. Hence the inclusion of
the metadata is fully justified as it leads to the increase of the number of analysed
impressions/review to more than
Number of identical words : 36
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 NJLjLjLj texts in which at least one keyword can
be found in the reviews’ title or content, as it is shown by experiments 3 and 4
Number of identical words : 25
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
fromTable 2.3.1. Analysing these results, we observe with high certainty that each
of the PageRank or Degree methods for computing keywords is better than tf-idf.
However, we note that the cross-checking of the list of obtained keywords with
the reviews’ title is not effective, as in most cases titles contain words that more
or less
Number of identical words : 54
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 summarise the reviews, while often the words occurring in the title are not
present in the review content. Moreover, we recommend to use only nouns and
adjectives as possible keywords, as in our experiments they gave the best results
with less computational effort.
Number of identical words : 42
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

Regarding cohesion and word distribution experiments, we were able to
Number of identical words : 10
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ob-
serve the small-world phenomenon in the majority of the
Number of identical words : 9
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 analysed networks. We
support this assumption by observing that the values of the average clustering
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 co-
efficient were higher than of randomly generated networks with the same number
vertices. The values of the Average Path Length and Diameter metrics were
Number of identical words : 23
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 rela-
tively low, compared to the number of vertices, as can be noticed in Figure
Number of identical words : 13
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 2.3.6
that displays the histogram of the obtained values for the Diameter metric. We
also observed that approximately
Number of identical words : 17
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ǎnj% of the networks had only one connected
component, while the rest had
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 NJ or Nj connected components. Moreover, every
network contained a Giant Component, containing more than
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ǑǍ% of the nodes.
Hence, even if
Number of identical words : 6
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 NJ or Nj components were found then one of them was the
Number of identical words : 9
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 domi-
nant, while the others were relatively small (counting the number of nodes). For
example, Figure
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 2.3.7 and 2.3.8 show the graphical representation of a network
with
Number of identical words : 8
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 NJ respectively Nj connected components. The presence of the small-world
phenomenon and dominance of one giant component confirms that the reviews
were not randomly, but rather naturally generated, as they were composed and
Number of identical words : 31
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

Number of identical words : 5

2.4 Conclusions & FutureWork

In this chapter, we have used several computationalmethods, techniques and tools
stemming fromvarious fields: ComplexNetworkAnalysis, Natural Language Pro-
cessing,GraphTheory, andGraphDatabases, to analyze a portal for sharing
Number of identical words : 6
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 touris-
tic opinions (AmFostAcolo). Theanalysiswas inspiredby theportal functionalities,
including question asking and answering, impression and review posting, as well
as commenting and echoing. The main goal of the study was to achieve a better
understanding of the touristic collaboration phenomenon.

Regarding the data extracted and
Number of identical words : 38
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 analysed from the question-answering func-
tionality, we draw a number of conclusions. We have proven the usefulness of
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 us-
ing theNeo4j graph databasemodel for retrieval of information that is relevant for
two real-world touristic scenarios. The network science experiments allowed us to
state that the network is stable and resilient, while continuing a cyclical trend of
Number of identical words : 34
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 ex-
pansion that attracts new users and then matures their connection. The presence
of various social phenomena has shown that the social environment has
Number of identical words : 22
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 merito-
cratic traits, i.e. users with
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 more intense activity are better trusted while acting as
Number of identical words : 9
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

76

Figure 2.3.7: AmFostAcolo’s example of a network with 2 connected
components. The radius of each node is proportional to its PageRank

coefficient. The
Number of identical words : 20
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 colour of each node denotes membership to a community, as
computed with the Modularity algorithm.
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

enhancers of information diffusion. Moreover, we have proven that information
travels fast and easy even if the source user is peripheral. We were able to identify
inner-communities of users and give evidence that the collaboration among the
communities is intense. We have also experimented and proposed a NLP-based
method to identify touristic traits of each community.

Using the texts extracted from the impression-echoing functionality, we
Number of identical words : 68
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 pro-
posed a new method, based on NS and NLP that is able to
Number of identical words : 12
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 summarise the texts
via keyword extraction. The results have shown that our two proposed methods
(Degree and PageRank) perform better than the widely used tf-idf information
Number of identical words : 26
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 re-
trieval method. Also, we have brought evidence that nouns and adjectives are the
parts of speech carrying out
Number of identical words : 17
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 themost relevant touristic information. Nevertheless,
the use of location metadata has proven useful for our experiments and we claim
Number of identical words : 18
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

77

Figure 2.3.8: AmFostAcolo’s example of a network with 3 connected
components. The radius of each node is proportional to its PageRank

coefficient. The
Number of identical words : 20
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 colour of each node denotes membership to a community, as
computed with the Modularity algorithm.
Number of identical words : 14
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

that it carries out relevant information. Furthermore,
Number of identical words : 7
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 wehave appliedNSmethods
to determine the cohesion of the posted reviews and their similarity to real-world
texts. This is useful to check that the reviews were not automatically generated by
Number of identical words : 28
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
software bots.

As a general conclusion, we have proven that our proposed approaches can
bring new valuable insights on how tourists collaborate via touristic portals.
Number of identical words : 23
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 How-
ever, we acknowledge that this study can be expanded by adding more touristic
scenarios and eventually also expanding the data model. A further analysis is
Number of identical words : 24
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 re-
quired towards inspecting visitation trends, based on previous studies of complex
Number of identical words : 10
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

78

networks. Regarding our proposed keyword
Number of identical words : 5
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 extractionmethods, we acknowledge
the fact that validating the keywords based
Number of identical words : 9
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf
 onwords in the title has its caveats, thus
other validation methods need to be developed. However, as current results have
shown our proposed method gives better results than tf-idf.
Number of identical words : 29
http://rochi.utcluj.ro/rrioc/articole/RRIOC-10-4-Becheru.pdf

79

I never teach my pupils. I only attempt to provide the condi-
tions in which they can learn.

Albert Einstein

3
Social Learning Environments

According to social learning theory
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [16]
, people can learn by observing
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 andmod-
elling the behaviour and attitudes of others. Understanding is socially constructed
by means of conversations and interactions around specific problems and
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 activi-
ties. Learning is seen as a product of participation in a community, rather than an
independent, individual process with social aspects
Number of identical words : 20
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [4]
. With the advent of social
media, learning by observing the activities, productions and discussions of experts
and peers is made possible on a new level
Number of identical words : 25
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [4][177]
.

Therefore, in recent years, social media tools have found their way into the
educational landscape, being used to foster communication and collaboration
Number of identical words : 22
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 be-
tween learners, help build communities and encourage positive interactions
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [69]
.
Practical usage scenarios for various categories of social media tools are well
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 sum-
marised in [54]
, [170]
. For example, wikis can be used to co-create content,
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 col-
laboratively edit a document, incrementally accumulate and
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 organise knowledge
and integrate resources from different web sources,
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 see [216]
. Blogs [213]
or
micro-blogging services [123]
can provide support for writing a group learning
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

80

diary, for creating an e-portfolio, for asking and receiving help from peers. Social
bookmarking tools
Number of identical words : 16
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [72]
canhelp students discover relevant educational resources,
which may be further tagged,
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 organised and shared with peers [177]
.

So far, few studies have explored the relations between students’
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 behaviour
in social media-based learning environments (i.e., patterns of interaction with the
tools) and their learning styles
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 [66, 179]
. Previous studies have found that: i)
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 ac-
tive students tend to post more frequently to their blogs than reflective students;
ii) reflective students’ ratio of reading other blog postings
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 versus posting to their
ownblogs is significantly higher than that of active students; iii) active students use
charts displaying the number of postings and peer rating more often than
Number of identical words : 24
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 reflec-
tive students; iv) sequential learners tend
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 towrite longer posts than global learners
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
[66]
.

With the expanding popularity of social media tools in Computer Supported
Collaborative Learning (CSCL), the need to examine how individual learners
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 in-
teract differently in online communities has increased. In this context,
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 we aim to
evaluate how the learners’ writing style in social media environments can be used
to predict their overall learning performance, as well as their individual learning
style. To do so, we use multiple textual complexity indices ranging from lexical,
syntactical to semantic analyses
Number of identical words : 43
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 [5]
, described in detail later on in this
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 chapter, to
create an in-depth perspective of each
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 learner’s writing style. This style analysis
creates a basis for predicting the overall performance of each learner in their
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 edu-
cational scenario, as well as for highlighting specific traits of their learning style.
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf

However, examining quantitative behaviour indicators is only one approach to
assessing learning
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 behaviour and success. Theother approach uses SocialNetwork
Analysis methods to examine students social behaviour and present it asmeaning-
ful knowledge to class instructors. Thus, we shall start by proposing a conceptual
knowledge extraction framework for social learning environments based on SNA.
Then, we shall conduct a framework directed analysis on real data gathered from a
CSCL course, with the purpose of validating and enhancing the proposed frame-
work. Last, but not least we shall introduce and develop a tool for analysing and
visualising students’ collaborations, orieted towards the average computer literate
instructor.

81

3.1 Background&RelatedWork

3.1.1 Educational Context

Theeducational contextwas a courseon ”WebApplicationsDesign” ( WAD) taught
to 4th year undergraduate students in Computer Science. A project-based
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 learn-
ing ( PBL) approach was used in which learning was
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 organised around the devel-
opment of web applications comprising of multiple state-of-the-art technologies.
Students collaborated in teams of 4 peers in order to build their chosen application
(e.g., a virtual bookstore, an online auction website, a professional social network,
an online travel agency, etc.).
Number of identical words : 43
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 In addition, students had to create four
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 compul-
sory intermediary presentations in order to be actively engaged throughout the
semester and to discourage the practice of
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 activity peaks at the end.

ThePBLscenariowas implemented inblendedmode,withweekly face-to-face
meetings between each team and their instructor. These meetings were
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 comple-
mented by the use of three social media tools (wiki, blog and a
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 micro-blogging
tool) for online communication and collaboration. MediaWiki1 was used for
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 col-
laborative writing tasks, for gathering and
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 organising team knowledge-base and
resources, and for documenting the project. Blogger2 was used for reporting the
progress of each project similar to a ”learning diary”, for publishing ideas and
Number of identical words : 30
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 re-
sources, as well as for providing feedback and solutions to peer problems. Each
team had its own blog, but inter-team cooperation was encouraged as well.
Number of identical words : 25
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 Twit-
ter3 wasmeant for encouraging additional connects to peers and for posting short
news, announcements, questions, and status updates regarding each project.

These three CSCL tools were all integrated in a social learning environment
called eMUSE
Number of identical words : 33
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 (empoweringMashUps for Social E-learning) [178]
. The platform
provided support for both students and teachers as a unique access point to the
social media tools, basic administrative services, learner tracking and data
Number of identical words : 26
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 visuali-
sations, aswell as evaluation and grading support.
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 eMUSE retrieves learner actions
from each of the disparate
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 Web 2.0 tools (by means of open APIs or Atom/RSS
feeds) and stores them in a local database, together with a description and an
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 as-

1http://www.mediawiki.org/
2www.blogger.com
3https://twitter.com

82

Table 3.1.1: Distribution of students and contributions per academic year.

3.1.2 Performance Analysis & Prediction

Automated prediction of student performance in technology enhanced learning
settings is a popular, yet complex research issue
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 [15, 191]
. The popularity comes
from the value of the predictive information which can be used for advising the
instructor about students at-risk, who are in need of more assistance
Number of identical words : 29
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 [158, 234]
.
More generally, automated methods offer instructors the ability to monitor
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 learn-
ing progress and provide personalised feedback and interventions to students in
any performance state
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 [232]
. In addition, individualised strategies for improving
participation may also be suggested
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 [234]
. Furthermore, a formative assessment
tool
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 couldbeenvisagedbasedon the automaticpredictionmechanism[234]
, which
has the potential to decrease instructors’ assessment loads
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 [232]
. Finally, students’
awareness can be increased by providing them prediction results and
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 personalised
feedback [232]
.

Performancepredictionhasbeenextensively studied inweb-basededucational
systems and, in particular, in
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 LearningManagement Systems (LMS).This is due to
the availability of large amounts of student
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 behavioural data, automatically logged
by these systems, such as: visits and session times, accessed resources, assessment
results, online activity and involvement in chats and forums, etc.
Number of identical words : 25
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 [191]
. Thus,
student performance prediction models based
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 onMoodle log data have been pro-
posed in multiple previous studies [48, 190, 236]
. Additionally, log data from in-
telligent tutoring systems (ITS) have also been used for performance prediction
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
[174]
. As far as computational techniques are involved, a wide variety of meth-
ods have been applied for predicting students’ performance, such as linear regres-

83

sion [186]
, neural network models [48]
, Support Vector Machines and k-nearest
neighbours [190]
, Bayesian networks [174]
, rank correlation analysis [66]
, mixed
effects analysis of variance (ANOVA) models
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 [123]
, principal component analy-
sis [97]
, as well as machine learning algorithms for classification, association rule
induction and feature selection
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 [179]
, or genetic algorithms [232, 236]
.

In contrast, students’ engagement with social media tools in emerging social
learning environments has been less investigated as a potential performance
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 pre-
dictor [97, 123]
. Some preliminary results suggest that the number of blog posts,
wiki page revisions, and shared bookmarks are reliable predictors of student
Number of identical words : 20
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 suc-
cess [97]
.

3.1.3 Textual Complexity Assessment

Textual complexity analysis can be used both for identifying the most
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 appropri-
ate reading material according to students’ comprehension level and for
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 assess-
ing students’ writing style and knowledge level from their writing traces, which is
our current research goal. According to
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 [8]
, measuring textual complexity can be
split into three perspectives: qualitative, reader/task orientation, and quantitative.
The qualitative dimensions of textual complexity cover various levels of meaning,
structure, language conventionality and knowledge requirements. Reader and task
considerations are associated with readers’ motivation, knowledge and interest.
Quantitative factors are the core of our analysis because they create the basis for
automated methods and tools which can be used to
Number of identical words : 67
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 analyse textual complexity.

Suchautomatedmethodshavebeendeveloped into frameworks thathavedemon-
strated success in understanding learning behaviours in collaborative learning en-
vironments [162]
. These frameworks include: Lexile (MetaMetrics), ATOS
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 (Re-
naissance Learning, Degrees of Reading Power: REAP (Carnegie Mellon
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 Univer-
sity), SourceRater (Educational Testing Service),Coh-Metrix (University
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 ofMem-
phis),TAALES andTAACO ( Georgia State University). The implemented
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 frame-
work that we use in this study,ReaderBench
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 [60, 61]
, covers a wide range of lexical,
syntactic, semantics and discourse
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 centred textual complexity indices, including
themost frequent indices from the above-mentioned systems.
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 In addition,Reader-
Bench focuses on text cohesion and discourse connectivity, and provides a more
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf

84

in-depth perspective of discourse structure based on Cohesion Network Analysis
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
[62]
. Cohesion Network Analysis is used to model the semantic links between
different text constituents in a multi-layered
Number of identical words : 15
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 cohesion graph [214]
. The following
subsections present the integrated dimensions of analyses possible within
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 Reader-
Bench (RB).

Surface Analysis

Categories like fluency, diction and basic readability formulas relying on surface
indices (e.g., words, commas, phrase length, periods) are computed in RB as a
way of evaluating lexical and syntactic levels of text difficulty. Page and Wresch
Number of identical words : 40
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
[172, 230]
have demonstrated that static attributes can effectively predict essay
scores.
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 Page’s work on quantifying an essay’s complexity has led to the
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 identifi-
cation of correlations between proxes (computer approximations of interest) and
human trins (intrinsic variables – human measures used for evaluation).
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 Start-
ing from Page’s metrics and taking into consideration
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 Slotnick’s categories [203]

grouping proxes based on their intrinsic values, multiple indices from their studies
have been integrated within our model including: average paragraph/ sentence/-
word lengths in characters, average and standard deviation of paragraph/sentence
lengths in words (including separate indices for unique content words), as well as
number of commas per sentence/paragraph. In addition, entropy
Number of identical words : 55
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 [199]
, which
can be defined as the expected value of the information contained in the text, is
used in RB to evaluate lexical diversity of word stems and characters within the
input text.
Number of identical words : 32
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf

Word Complexity

In the first step of the RB processing, words are extracted from the input text.
A Natural Language Processing (NLP) pipeline then splits the words, tokenizes
them, eliminates stop words, and then conducts Part Of Speech (POS) tagging,
lemmatization, parsing and Named Entity Recognition (NER)
Number of identical words : 47
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 [145]
. RB cal-
culates a number of indices for content words in the text. These indices include
syllable count, distance between the inflected form, lemma and stem, corpus frequency,
distance within the hypernym tree and word polysemy. These indices are used to
Number of identical words : 38
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 ap-

85

proximate each word’s individual complexity. Corpus frequency is computed as an
inverse frequency of words from the training corpora, while polysemy is computed
on the basis of the lexicalized ontology WordNet
Number of identical words : 28
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 [156]
. In general, words with
multiple senses have a higher complexity because it is harder to assign the correct
sense to them. The distance within the hypernym tree is related to a
Number of identical words : 31
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 word’s speci-
ficity and is determined as the distance to the
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 ontology’s root; longer paths usually
indicate
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 specialisation or specificity for given words. In addition, the differences
between the inflected form, the lemma and the stem reveal the use of multiple
Number of identical words : 23
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 jux-
taposed prefixes and suffixes, which is another mark of a word with a higher
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 com-
plexity.

Syntax

Themost predictive POS tags in terms of textual complexity are prepositions,
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 ad-
jectives and adverbs [162]
that allow for a more detailed and complex text
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 struc-
ture. In addition, RB uses a syntactic parser to calculate a number of syntactic
indices (e.g., overall size of the parsing tree, maximum depth, number of semantic
Number of identical words : 27
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 de-
pendencies). Higher values for these indices usually indicate greater complexity
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
[96]
.

Semantics

According to McNamara et al.[
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 149]
, textual complexity is also linked to
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 cohe-
sion with regard to text comprehension. Cohesion is a central element for
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 ob-
taining a coherent mental representation of discourse, commonly called a
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 situa-
tio model [221]
. Therefore, texts that lack cohesion may be perceived as having
a higher difficulty due to an increased cognitive load on the part of the reader.
In RB, a cohesion graph is used to model the underlying structure of discourse
Number of identical words : 39
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
[214]
. Cohesion is determined at both inter- and intra- paragraph levels of
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 analy-
sis based on three semantic distances: a) Wu-Palmer semantic similarity
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 inWord-
Net [231]
, b) cosine similarity usingLatent SemanticAnalysis vector spaces [133]

and c) Jensen-Shannon dissimilarity between Latent Dirichlet topic distributions
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
[31]
. In general, a text ismore complex as the number of relevant links in the
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 cohe-
sion graph increases. Thus, the average value of all the inter- and intra- paragraph
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf

86

links reflects text complexity [214]
. In addition, specific discourse connectors
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 de-
fined as cue phrases are also considered in order to evaluate the degree of discourse
elaboration.

Named entity derived features also influence comprehension, because they
create the basic components of concepts and propositions on which higher-level
Number of identical words : 36
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
discourseprocessing is based [78]
. Therefore indexesbasedonnamedentity statis-
tics are also included in the RB framework.
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf

Social Network Analysis

Since eMUSE supports the creation of learning networks, which can be
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 modelled
as social graphs, a knowledge extraction process can be performed by applying
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 So-
cial Network Analysis (SNA) methods [20, 196]
.

SNAhas also been used in technology-enhanced learning area, as
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 summarised
in [189]
. The paper focuses especially on the use of collaborative filtering
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 tech-
niques, which can generate personalised recommendations for students; learning
objects, relevant links, relevant courses or most appropriate study partners can be
the subject of these recommendations. Various communication aspects, patterns
of academic collaboration and the structure of online learning communities have
also been investigated, according to
Number of identical words : 41
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [189]
.

More recently, Maglajlic and Gutl
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [143]
also used SNA in an educational
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 en-
vironment in order to observe, measure, enhance collaboration and as an early
detection method of potential weak trainees. Also, they proposed a social
Number of identical words : 22
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 engi-
neering algorithmwith the purpose of placing a trainee in the appropriate tutored
group. The authors employed SNA techniques such as cliques, centrality and
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 den-
sity. Furthermore, the authors brought evidence that the efficiency of digital
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 learn-
ing environments can be monitored through SNA.

Crespo and Antunes
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [55]
focused their attention on the representation and
analysis of teamwork in an educational context. They found that SNA can be used
with success in representing, exploring and predicting teamwork results. As SNA
techniques, the authors used diverse variants of the PageRank algorithm for
Number of identical words : 43
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 rank-
ing learners.

Haythornthwaite [106]
also investigated social networks analysismethods and

87

metrics for e-learning, based on specific educational needs. The following SNA
methods were selected for use: number of ties, density, centrality and cliques. The
authors further discussed the perspectives of SNA for understanding social
Number of identical words : 35
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 learn-
ing in [107]
. In addition to an overview on the use of SNA techniques in
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 learn-
ing networks, the paper includes a discussion on how to create/interpret a social
graph.
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 Indesigningour framework,we tried to answer
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 someof thequestions raised
by the authors, e.g. What metrics matter for networked learning?
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [107]
.

As for software tools used for SNA analysis we mention those that we will use
extensively throughout this chapter, while otherswill bementionedwhereneeded.
Gephi 4 is a visualisation and exploration software for graphs. Pajek
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 5 is a software
tool for large graph analysis; although it
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 lacksGephi’s ease of use, it comprisesmany
more SNAmethods. NetworkX 6 [105]
andGraphViz7 representmature program-
ming libraries oriented on the study of graphs.
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

Information Visualisation

Information visualisation relies on the remarkable visual perception abilities of
Number of identical words : 8
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 hu-
mans for pattern discovery [233]
. It employs interactive visual representations in
order to amplify cognition
Number of identical words : 10
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 [223]
and generate insight [46]
.

Visual approaches have been used in learning analytics, to help teachers and
students explore learner traces from virtual learning environments. Various types
of data can be included in a learning analytics dashboard, such as:
Number of identical words : 34
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 artefacts pro-
ducedby learners, social interaction, resourceuse, time spent, test and self-assessment
results. The goal is to provide insight into learning data, supporting awareness and
decision making, and increasing students’ engagement and motivation
Number of identical words : 27
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 [223]
.

Networks or graphs are a common
Number of identical words : 6
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visualisation method in educational set-
tings [46]
. They can be used to display information regarding students’
Number of identical words : 9
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 interac-
tions, which is particularly important in case of collaborative learning and social
learning environments.
Number of identical words : 13
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0

In particular, social network analysis (SNA) and network
Number of identical words : 8
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visualisations have
4https://gephi.org/
5http://vlado.fmf.uni-lj.si/pub/networks/Pajek/
6https://networkx.github.io/
7https://graphviz.org/

88

been used to investigate students’ interactions taking place in educational
Number of identical words : 10
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 environ-
ments [55, 189]
.

3.2 Predicting Students’ Performance andDifferences

The approach that we propose in this
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 section is based on the content analysis of
each
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 student’s contributions as opposed to student
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 behaviours. Specifically, in this
study, we apply textual complexity analyses on blog entries and tweets posted by
Number of identical words : 16
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
students in the context of
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 eMUSE collaborative project-based learning scenario.
We also use survey results to assess students’ learning styles. We use the textual
analysis to predict learning outcomes and learning styles.
Number of identical words : 27
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf

In the following we introduce two sets of experiments. The first one analyses a
broader range of data in order to obtain a general perspective. The second experi-
ments reduces the range of the data used for a more in depth perspective.
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf

3.2.1 Data Acquisition & Preprocessing

Data Acquisition

For the first experiment, data was collected over 6 consecutive winter semesters
(2010/2011 – 2015/2016),
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 from the WAD course. Small improvements and re-
finements were made from one year to the consecutive one, based on students’
feedback and instructor experience. A total of 343 students, enrolled in the WAD
course, participated in this
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 experiment. For details on thenumberof contributions
see section 3.1.1.

For the second experiment, the data was collected during the first semester of
the 2013-2014 academic
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 during the WAD course. The participants in the second
experiment consisted of ǎǎ undergraduate students split into ljǏ teams (ljǎ with nj
members and ljwith NJmembers). For the current experiment, the writing actions
we used to assess student writing style were students’ tweets, together with their
blog posts and comments. The total number of student contributions recorded at
the end of the semester included
Number of identical words : 34
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 ljǍǎlj tweets, ǏLjǐ blog posts and Njǎǎ blog com-
ments.

According to Keefe [126]
, learning styles refer to the individual manner in
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf

89

which a person approaches a learning task, as well as their preferences related to
perception modality, processing and
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 organising information, reasoning or social
aspects. Various learning
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 stylemodelshavebeenproposedduring thepastdecades,
which differ in terms of the underlying learning theories, as well as the number
and descriptions of included dimensions. One of the most popular models in
technology-enhanced learning is FSLSM proposed by Felder and Silverman
Number of identical words : 36
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 [66,
77]
. According to FSLSM, learners are
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 categorised in terms of their preferences
based on four dimensions: a) active versus reflective; b) sensing versus intuitive;
c) visual versus verbal and d) sequential versus global
Number of identical words : 26
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 [77]
.

To collect students’ learning styles according to FSLSM
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 [77]
we used a dedi-
cated inventory: the Index of Learning Styles questionnaire (ILS)
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 [205]
. The ILS
consisted of njnj questions, each with two possible answers. As a result of the test,
the learning style of the student
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 was described on a scale between
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 Оljlj and +ljlj
(with a step of += О NJ) for each FSLSM dimension. As an example, a score of
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
+ljlj on the active/reflective dimension implies a strong active preference, while
a score of
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 ОNj implies a mild reflective preference. The ILS questionnaire was not
mandatory, and, as a result, only
Number of identical words : 16
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 njǐ students completed it.

Data Preprocessing

Datapreprocessingwasnecessarybecausemany texts containedelements that added
no value to our research (e.g., HTML tags, images, emoticons, references to other
students, computer code, URLs). Also, students used both English (second
Number of identical words : 26
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 lan-
guage) and Romanian (native) languages in their blog and Twitter contributions.
However, textual complexity cannot be performed in a cross-
Number of identical words : 19
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 languagemanner due
to each language’s specificity. Thus, we had to separate English from Romanian
texts. For the purpose of this study, only English contributions were considered.

The first preprocessing step focusing on cleaning the input texts was
Number of identical words : 31
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 automat-
ically performed bymeans of an extension of the BeautifulSoup
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 8 library. After ap-
plying the previous cleaningmechanisms, we performed language detection based
on the langdetect
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 9 library (ported from Google’s language detection software).
Next we filtered in only the students who had at least five English contributions
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf

8https://pypi.python.org/pypi/beautifulsoupnj
9https://pypi.python.org/pypi/langdetect

90

after preprocessing. Also, a threshold of minimum 50 content words was consid-
ered for our textual complexity analysis.
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 We defined a content word as dictionary
word, we do not consider stop-words ( common words with little meaning - e.g.,
“and”, “the”, “an”), which has as corresponding part-of-speech a noun, verb,
Number of identical words : 20
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 adjec-
tive or adverb.

Thus, for the first experiment a total of 148 students were included in our
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 anal-
ysis, having cumulatively 3013 textual contributions.
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 Next we modelled the data
as one week time-frames (i.e., 7 days starting from each consecutiveMonday) due
to the schedule of the academic semester in which students had one WAD class
per week. The total length of the considered time series is 16 weeks, including 14
weeks of classes and 2weeks for
Number of identical words : 37
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 thewinter holidays. For each student, the number
of weekly blog
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 andmicro-blog posts was computed in order to obtain his/her time
series of social media contributions.
Number of identical words : 15
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf

As the amount of data for the second experiment was less than in the first ex-
periment, manual language corrections were done (i.e., spelling). Besides spell-
checking, we also enriched the texts with expanded Twitter tags, if present. For
example, if a semantically relevant twitter
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 tagwas found (e.g., #workinghard), then
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
thewords containedwithin the tagwere extracted and added to the text. Thus, our
statistical analysis for the second experiment was performed on 29 students
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 hav-
ing 848 textual contributions, out of which 27 finished the course and only 25
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 had
completed the ILS questionnaire.

3.2.2 Results &Discussion

First Experiment

The performed longitudinal analysis relies on a wide range of evolution indices
including average & standard deviation of contributions, entropy, uniformity, local
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 ex-
treme points, and average & standard deviation of recurrence. We refer readers to
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 [5]

for further information about these features that were initially used for keystroke
analysis.
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf

We split the students into two equitable groups: high performance students
with grades
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 ǐ, while the rest were catalogued as low performance students. The
indices from ReaderBench and from the longitudinal analysis that lacked normal
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf

distributions were discarded. Correlations were then calculated for the

Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 < :LjǍ) and meaningful

Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 > :lj) between the selected indices and the
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf

pendent variable (the students’ final score in the course). Indices that were highly
collinear (r:
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 ǑLjLj) were flagged, and the index with the strongest correlation with
course grade was retained, while the other indices were removed. The remaining
indices were included as predictor variables in a stepwise multiple regression to
explain the variance in the students’ final scores in
Number of identical words : 43
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 theWAD course, as well as pre-
dictors in a Discriminant Function Analysis
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 [15]
used to classify students based
on their performance.

Medium to weak effects were found for ReaderBench indices related to word
entropy, number of verbs, prepositions, adverbs, and pronouns, the number of
unique words, number of named entities per sentence, and average cohesion
Number of identical words : 42
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 be-
tween sentences and corresponding contributions measured with Latent Dirichlet
Allocation
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 [60]
(see Table 3.2.1).

Weconducted a stepwise regression analysis using the ten significant indices as
the independent variables. This yielded a significant model, F(
Number of identical words : 19
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 Nj; ljnjNj) = ljǏ:ǐǑNj,
p < :LjLjlj, r = :ǍNJlj, RNJ = :NJǏNJ. Three variables were significant and positive
predictors of course grades: word entropy, time series entropy and average verbs
in sentence, denoting a higher activity and participation for high performance
Number of identical words : 29
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 stu-
dents. These variables explained NJǏ% of the variance in the students’ final scores
for the course.
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf

Second Experiment

Due to the limited amount of data and the need to control for over-fitting, 2-tailed

Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf

Number of identical words : 8

Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
3.2.3).

Afterwards, a stepwise Discriminant Function Analysis (DFA) was used to

classify students on each learning style dimension. For this analysis, +/-1 and+/-3
values (as resulted from the ILS questionnaire) were considered neutral, whereas
the other values per dimension were catalogued as positive/negative. As with the
regression analysis, only the top 3 indices with the highest effect size were
Number of identical words : 64
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 consid-
ered in order to control for
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 over-fitting.

Regarding theActive/ReflectiveDimension, the stepwiseDFAretained twovari-
ables and removed the remaining variables as non-significant predictors. The
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 re-
sults demonstrate that the DFA using these two indices correctly allocated 15 of
the 25 texts in the total set for an accuracy of
Number of identical words : 23
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 ǎLj% ( the chance level for this
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 anal-
ysis is NjNj%). See Table 3.2.4 for variables and results. The measure of agreement
between the actual text type and that assigned by the model produced a weighted
Number of identical words : 22
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
Cohen’s Kappa of Lj:NJǍǎ, demonstrating fair agreement

For the Sensing/Intuitive Dimension, the stepwise DFA indicated that no
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 vari-
ables were predictive of the sensing – intuitive dimension.
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf

and removed the remaining variables as non-significant predictors. The results
demonstrate that the DFA using these three indices correctly allocated
Number of identical words : 30
