texts in the total set for an accuracy of
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 njǐ% (the chance level for this analysis is
NjNj%). SeeTable 3.2.4 for variables and results. Themeasureof agreementbetween
the actual text type and that assigned by the model produced a weighted
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 Cohen’s
Kappa of Lj:ljǐǐ, demonstrating fair agreement.

3.3 Conceptual Knowledge Extraction Framework

Investigating students’ interactions and the collaborative learning processes
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 tak-
ing place in these social learning environments is an important research direction,
which could bring valuable insight
Number of identical words : 16
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 into the collaborative learning process.
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 Hence,
what we propose in this
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 section is a conceptual framework for knowledge
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 extrac-
tion and visualisation from a social media-based learning environment. In
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 par-
ticular, we will focus on eMUSE platform, proposed in [178]
; more details about

95

Table 3.3.1: Extracted set of Knowledge Needs

ID Short Description
KN1 Determine the collaboration network.

KN2 Determine methods to quantify collaboration over various time intervals
Number of identical words : 25
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 andvarious network granularities.
KN3 Determine salient students or communities of students.
KN4 Determine if the course environment adequately supports collaboration.
KN5 Determine external factors that influence the evolution of collaboration.
KN6 Determine the impact of instructors’ actions on collaboration.
KN7 Determine clear and comprehensive methods of presenting the information extracted.
Number of identical words : 54
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

eMUSE areprovided in section3.1.1. Thedeclaredobjectiveof theproposed frame-
work is to identify appropriate SNA techniques and integrate them in a conceptual
knowledge extraction framework.
Number of identical words : 15
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

3.3.1 Basis & Rationale

Our framework proposal builds on the previous papers,
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 see section 3.1.3, and aims
to coverSNAmethods thathave thepotential to answer specific instructional needs
and have been proven useful in similar scenarios.
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 Theproposed conceptual knowl-
edge extraction framework is designedon thebasis of eMUSE [178]
social learning
environment. Hence, we will select only
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 SNAmethods that could be used on the
data provided by eMUSE. Furthermore, the analysis methods have to address
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 cer-
tain knowledge needs defined by instructors working with eMUSE.
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

Knowledge Needs

The general purpose of our framework is to provide useful knowledge from the
instructors’ point of view. Hence, we asked the teachers working with eMUSE
to define their knowledge needs (KN). Next, we filtered the
Number of identical words : 37
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 KN by keeping only
those that we could partially/totally quantify and satisfy through the use of SNA
methods/techniques. Then, a series of refinement and clustering stages were
Number of identical words : 28
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 con-
ducted through the instructors’ continuous feedback. The compiled list of
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 ex-
tracted knowledge needs is included in Table
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 3.3.1.

KN 1 is an obvious need as there cannot be any analysis without building the
collaboration network. This need will be treated in the next subsection.
Number of identical words : 26
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

96

KN2 implies theuseof currentSNAmethods andpossibledevelopment/adap-
tation of new techniques to capture collaboration. The development/adaptation
of new methods is justified by their use in a new context, the digital learning
Number of identical words : 24
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 con-
text.

Salient students or communities are those that
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 areusually at thehigh endof the
collaboration spectrum. By satisfying KN 3 instructors should be able to pinpoint
students / communities
Number of identical words : 15
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 thatmostly support collaboration. Also, instructors could
be presented with early warnings for students / communities that do not engage
in collaboration, those with
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 possible low learning outcomes.

By course environment we refer both to the platform used in the course (in
our case, eMUSE in conjunction with several social media tools), and to the
Number of identical words : 30
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 ped-
agogical scenario set by the course instructor (in our case, group project-based
learning). The environment is an important factor in the evolution of any
Number of identical words : 24
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 collab-
oration network. Hence, knowing if the course environment adequately supports
collaboration (KN 4) is a valuable affordance.

KN5 addresses the discovery of external factors that influence the evolution of
the collaboration network. We define external factors as those which are not
Number of identical words : 41
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 con-
trolled by the instructor, e.g. social phenomena or students’ habits
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [215]
, [157]
.
Having an insight on the presence of such phenomena/habits would give the
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 in-
structor additional leverage. For example, the presence
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 on preferential attachment
phenomenon could explain a high rate of collaboration among some learners.

By satisfying KN 6, teachers would get the means of evaluating their actions
based on the impact on the collaboration network.

Instructors should be presented with extracted knowledge in a clear manner,
that is easy to understand (KN 7). Thus, the framework adoption effort would be
reduced and the focus would shift to the benefits it provides.
Number of identical words : 68
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

Constructing the Social Graph

As already mentioned, the objects of study of our framework are social graphs. A
social graph is a graph where persons are depicted through vertices/nodes.
Number of identical words : 30
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 Rela-
tions among vertices are an abstraction of an interaction manner. In our context,
vertices represent learners and interactions
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 representmessages exchanged through

97

the social media tools integrated in eMUSE.
Graph theory defines two manners of representing relations among vertices:

oriented
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 edges (arcs) and non-oriented edges ( links). We argue that human
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 com-
munication usually implies bidirectional relations; thus, the use of arcs may lead
to an oversimplification, as opposed to the use of links. However, by using arcs
we can extract knowledge on leadership and pro-activity. Hence, we are
Number of identical words : 37
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 advocat-
ing the use of both methods for representing social relations, as we can capture
diverse facets of inter-human communication.

Since eMUSE provides a data
Number of identical words : 24
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 collectionmechanismwhich records student in-
teractions on social media, we can easily develop software tools to extract social
graphs. We can enrich
Number of identical words : 16
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 these social graphs by incorporating the time of message
exchanges as an attribute of the arcs/links. Thus, we will be able to develop time-
series analyses as requested by KN 2. Furthermore, we can add weights to the
arcs/links in order to capture the number of messages exchanged between two
students. In addition, the weight can be coupled with the length of the messages
(number of characters)
Number of identical words : 69
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 or other measures, to better capture the quantitative
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 as-
pect of communication. Also, other qualitative measures can be used as weighting
methods, which we need to identify.

We aim to create asmany relevant social graphs as possible, from various facets
of communication. We define a facet as a unique way of communication based on
the type, digital tool, purpose, etc. Also, graphs can be obtained through
Number of identical words : 34
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 aggrega-
tion of various other graphs. In our case, we could aggregate the social graphs for
each social media tool present in eMUSE, thus obtaining a social graph capturing
all communication established through the platform.

We consider that the above discussion fully addresses KN 1 (Determine the
collaboration network) for our scenario; hence, in what follows we will only focus
on the other KNs.
Number of identical words : 62
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

3.3.2 Conceptual Framework Design

Based on the
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 knowledge needs defined in section 3.3.1 and on our experience in
using SNA, we identified some methods of knowledge extraction. We consider
these methods adequate for our analysis scenario, with a high probability of being
Number of identical words : 29
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

98

Table 3.3.2: SNA methods for the graph as a whole perspective

Method KN addressed
Graph Connectivity:
No. of connected components, Line connectivity KN 2, KN 4, KN 6

Information Diffusion:
Diameter,
Number of identical words : 29
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 Avg. shortest path KN 2, KN 4, KN 6

Graph Clustering:
Global
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 avg. clustering coefficient, No. of K-cliques KN 2, KN 4, KN 6

Graph ability to support information exchange KN 4, KN 6
Models of network growth KN5
Number of identical words : 28
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
Visualisation:
Force directed (Force Atlas2, Fruchterman-Reingold), Bow-tie structure KN 7
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

useful in similar scenarios; however, we do not imply that the selection is
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 exhaus-
tive. For each method, we will mention the knowledge need(s) that it is able to
partially/totally satisfy and give short examples of their respective affordances for
an instructor.

The proposed conceptual framework is structured to address three levels of
graph granularity. The first level investigates the social graph as a whole. The
Number of identical words : 53
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 sec-
ond level addresses communities that appear inside the graph. Individual vertices
in the graph are studied through the
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 framework’s third level. Hence, wewill be able
to explain general traits through
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 individual/group particularities and vice versa.
Last but not least, time series analysis perspective will be discussed.
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 As we cannot
possibly present each SNA method in detail,
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 we refer the reader to fundamental
works such as
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [20, 34, 58, 119]
.

Whole Graph Perspective

From the perspective of the whole graph, we selected the set of
Number of identical words : 15
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 SNAmethods in-
cluded in Table 3.3.2.

In our educational context, graph connectivity refers to the paths of
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 communi-
cation between learners. The number of connected components is inversely
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 corre-
lated with the ability of the graph to support communication between learners. A
connected component can be considered a communication silo; no communication
is possible with members that are not part of the component. Thus, the number
of connected components could be seen as a marker for collaboration. In the case
Number of identical words : 50
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

99

of only one strong connected component, we can use line connectivity as another
marker for collaboration. Line connectivity is defined as the minimum number
of edges whose deletion from a graph would lead to an increase in the number of
connected components. The higher the value of line connectivity the more
Number of identical words : 51
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 commu-
nication paths exist; hence, the higher probability of successful collaboration.

In addition, we define information diffusion as the number of steps it takes for
information to spread out in the entire graph, if it is passed from one learner to
another. Hence, in our graph representation of information diffusion is related with
paths in the graph. The diameter of a graph is the longest shortest path between
any pair of vertices. The average shortest path is computed as the average value of
all shortest paths in the graph. The lower the
Number of identical words : 90
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 valueof the abovementionedmetrics,
themore direct communication there is. Hence, increasing the chances of
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 success-
ful collaborations. Therefore, information diffusionmethods are yet another way to
capture and evaluate collaboration.

In the real world, people tend to bond together and communities of people
arise. Hence, it is obvious that the more bonding there is the more paths of
Number of identical words : 37
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 com-
munication emerge. The global clustering coefficient represents an overall graph
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
measureof thedegree towhich vertices in a graph tend to cluster together. Another
measure to capture the clustering effect is determining the number of K-cliques. A
clique represents a complete
Number of identical words : 27
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 sub-graph of K vertices. Since in our PBL scenario
learners using eMUSE generally form teams of 4 members, we would expect the
number of 4-cliques to be at least equal to the number of teams. Otherwise, it would
mean that there are teams where not all members communicate directly, leading
to potentially low collaboration and poor course outcomes.

The ability of a social graph to support knowledge / information exchange is
Number of identical words : 70
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 es-
sential inour scenario, as it affects learners’ capability to receive and transmit
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 knowl-
edge. An instructor possessing such an insight can act
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 tomodify the social graph to
better support knowledge exchange, e.g. encourage active learners to share
Number of identical words : 15
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 knowl-
edge among each other. More details on how to determine a
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 graph’s ability to sup-
port information exchange can be found in
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [22]
.

In addition to the traits which can be influenced by the instructor, the graph
could exhibit also other traits that appear due to social phenomena or peculiar
habits present among the community of learners. Determining the evolutionary
Number of identical words : 37
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

100

Table 3.3.3: SNA methods for the communities perspective

Method KN addressed
Community detection:
Graph clustering, Modularity KN 1-7

Important parts discovery:
Strong component detection, Island detection, K-cores detection KN 1-7

Transformation
Number of identical words : 32
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 & Visualisation:
Reduction, Context, Dendrogram KN 1-7
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

mechanism of the network through
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 themodel of network growth [164]
, could lead
to identifying external factors that impact the collaboration network.

Finally, in order to satisfy knowledge need 7, we will introduce graph
Number of identical words : 23
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 draw-
ing methods in our framework. We consider graph
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 visualisations as an easy way
to evaluate communication. Force-directed drawing algorithms (e.g., Force Atlas 2
Number of identical words : 16
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
[119]
and Fruchterman-Reingold [88]
) present graphs in an aesthetically pleasant
way, with no additional requirements from the instructor, e.g.: as few crossings of
links as possible;
Number of identical words : 23
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 positioningof learners in a gradientway,withmost active learners
in the centre; learners belonging to the same community plotted in close vicinity
etc
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

Communities Perspective

We use the term community for a group of learners that communicate/collaborate
together significantly more than with other learners.
Number of identical words : 20
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 From the perspective of the
learning communities that appear inside a graph, we selected the set of
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 SNAmeth-
ods included in Table 3.3.3.

A number of methods can be used for community detection. Graph clustering
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
[132]
is the task of grouping the vertices of a graph into communities taking into
consideration the arcs/links. For an easy visualization of the arrangement of
Number of identical words : 26
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 clus-
ters we can use dendrograms. Modularity
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [131]
measures the strength and division
of the network in communities. Hence, it can be used as a method to determine
communities.

Important parts discovery refers to identifying
Number of identical words : 27
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 subgraphswithpeculiar attributes
for further analysis. A strongly connected component of a directed graph is a
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 maxi-
mal subgraph where there is a path between all vertices. Island detection represents
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

101

amethod to identify relevant parts of a network usually by inspecting the
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 distribu-
tion of vertices or arcs’/links’ values. A K-core
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [131]
is a maximal subgraph with
the property that all vertices in the subgraph have a degree equal or higher than K.
Thus, we consider K-core detection as a method of discovering important parts.

Having identified the learning communities, we can further
Number of identical words : 42
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 analyse each one.
Considering that a part or a community is a subgraph, which in turn is a graph, we
can
Number of identical words : 20
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 analyse it with all the methods present in our proposed framework; thus all
knowledge needs can be covered.

A reduction of a graph represents the merging of constituent parts (e.g.
Number of identical words : 30
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 com-
munities) into a vertex for each part (Vpart). Links/arcs between initial vertices
of the same constituent part are suppressed. Initial links/arcs between vertices of
different constituent parts become links/arcs between their respective Vparts. A
context transformation is similar to a reduction, with the exception that one initial
part is preserved as it is. A graphical illustration of the above mentioned
Number of identical words : 62
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 transfor-
mations for our learning scenario can be seen in
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 Figure 3.3.1.

Visualising communities/parts and their respective bridges of communication
exchange represents a quick and intuitive manner of informing instructors on the
general knowledge exchange status. Hence, teachers can easily identify
Number of identical words : 29
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 communi-
ties that require additional attention. For example, reduction transformation could
be used to evaluate inter-team communication. In our scenario, this type of
Number of identical words : 22
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 com-
munication is neither restricted nor endorsed by the instructors; thus, it is of
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 in-
terest to see if learners break the team boundary and engage in communication
with other fellow learners. Context transformation could be further used to
Number of identical words : 23
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 pin-
point the students, from a specific team, who are engaging in inter-team
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 commu-
nication ( e.g., student E from
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 Figure 3.3.1).

Individual Perspective

From the perspective of the individual learners inside the graph, we selected the
set of
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 SNAmethods included in Table 3.3.4.

Centralitymeasuresquantify vertices’ importance fromagraph theory perspec-
tive [58]
. In our scenario, these methods try to
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 asses each learner’s collaboration

102

Figure 3.3.1: Graph transformation example; the colour of each vertex defines
team membership: students A-D belong to Team ”red” and students E-G

belong to Team ”green”.
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

activity. One of the most popular centrality measures is the degree of the vertex.
This metric could be used to easily determine the learners that are the most/least
active. However, this is a quantitative measure, which gives no indication
Number of identical words : 40
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 regard-
ing the quality of the interactions between the students. Hence, a more suitable
centrality measure could be PageRank
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [173]
, Eigenvector [35]
or Katz [125]
, as
they take into consideration qualitative aspects of communication. Salient
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 learn-
ers ( i.e., those with particularly high or low activity), could be determined by
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 or-
dering students based on the above centrality measures.

Through the information
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 cyclemethods, we are trying to assesswhich learners
are the sources of information (Hubs) and which learners are the sinks for
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 infor-
mation (Authorities) [127]
.

In a graph, a vertex’s positioning is of great importance as it may be a critical
point in maintaining certain graph traits, e.g. connectivity. Hence, learners
Number of identical words : 22
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 repre-
sented through such vertices are salient. Through Betweenness an instructor can
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

103

Table 3.3.4: SNA methods for the communities perspective

Method KN addressed
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
Measures of centrality:
Degree, PageRank, Katz,
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 Eigenvector KN 2, KN 3, KN 6

Information cycle:
Hubs, Authorities KN 2, KN 3

Positioning:
Closeness coefficient, Local clustering coefficient, Betweenness KN 2, KN 3
Number of identical words : 25
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

Visualisation:
Vertez/link scaling, colouring & shaping, Bow-tie structure KN 7
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

determine the learners that bridge community silos, those learners that facilitate
the exchange of knowledge between communities. The Local clustering coefficient
is similar with
Number of identical words : 24
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 theGlobal clustering coefficient (introduced in 3.3.2), with the differ-
ence that it measures a vertex’s tendency to communicate with others. The
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 Close-
nessmetric is computed as the sum of the lengths of the shortest paths between a
vertex and all other vertices in the graph. Hence, learners with low Closeness
Number of identical words : 27
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 val-
ues are positioned on various communication paths, playing an important role in
knowledge diffusion.

By using the above mentioned methods, instructors should be able to
Number of identical words : 24
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 deter-
mine the status of each learner involvement and their recognition by other
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 learn-
ers. These insights can be included in the grading methodology, harnessing and
encouraging valuable learners.

A bow-tie
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 [40]
graphical representation of the social graph is able to
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 categorise
learners in four categories: sharing information, sharing and acquiring, only
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 ac-
quiring and inactive students. Such a method provides useful information in an
easy to understand manner. Through scaling,
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 colouring & shaping of links and ver-
tices we can present various attributes in graph drawings, hence making it easy for
instructors to
Number of identical words : 15
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 visualise multiple facets of communication in a graph
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 representa-
tion.

Time-Series Perspective

The time series perspective is a valuable complementary method for all the three
graph granularity perspectives. It represents a recurrent application of the above
Number of identical words : 27
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
mentionedSNAmethods at certainpoints in timeor for certain time-frames. Hence,

104

the evolution of the social network can be
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 visualised throughout time. In addition,
the instructor can investigate inflection points and correlate them with learning
activities; thus, important affordances can be extracted and harnessed. The time
series perspective was introduced to satisfy KN 2.
Number of identical words : 34
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

3.4 InvestigatingStudents’CollaborationPatterns ineMUSE

In the previous section we have introduced a conceptual knowledge extraction
framework to explore the collaborative learning process.
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 For the current section
we plan to experimentally validate the proposed
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 framework by exploring the col-
laborative learning process supported by eMUSE environment and
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 its integrated
social media tools. More specifically, we will investigate students’ collaboration
patterns in a project-based learning scenario and use SNA to extract knowledge
that answers instructors’ pedagogical needs,
Number of identical words : 25
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 see Table 3.3.1.

3.4.1 CollaborationOverview: Building the Social Graph

Data Source

For this study, we took into account the 2016-2017 instalment of a course on ”Web
Applications Design”, taught to 4th year undergraduate students in Computer
Number of identical words : 16
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Sci-
ence in the first semester of the
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 academic year, for more details on the course refer
to section 3.1.1

A total of NjNJ students participated in the study, being split in
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 ǐ teams (nj stu-
dents per team). Thenumberof student actionson the socialmedia tools, recorded
by eMUSE at the end of the semester, included
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 ljǎǐǎ tweets, NJǏlj blog entries (ljǍǑ
posts and ljljNJ comments) and ljǎǑǎwiki page revisions and file uploads.
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

In the current analysis, we are interested in students’ communication and
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 col-
laboration patterns; since the wiki actions log did not include explicit information
on students’ interactions, we excluded them from this analysis. We therefore take
into account students’ communication on the Blog and Twitter, as described next.
Number of identical words : 35
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

105

Building the Social Graph

Acustom toolwasdesigned and implemented for processing the
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 rawdata collected
by eMUSE; Python 3.5 programming language with NetworkX graph analysis
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 li-
brary were employed for building the social graph.
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 This tool was designed to re-
spect the principles enunciated in section 3.3.1 of the proposed conceptual frame-
work.

More specifically, a directed graph was built starting from students’
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 interac-
tions on the blog and micro-blogging tool; vertices represent learners and links
represent messages exchanged through the two social media tools integrated in
eMUSE. The types of interactions (collaborations) taken into account on Blogger
and Twitter respectively are detailed next.

Regarding the Blog, since each team has one common blog space, we assume
that each post is addressed to the corresponding team members. Hence, for each
blog post we consider a collaboration between the author of the post (source
Number of identical words : 73
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 stu-
dent) and each respective team peer (target students). Thus,
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 njǏǏ collaborations
(i.e., ljǍǑposts О Nj team members) are considered. In addition, each blog
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 com-
ment is directly addressed to the initial blog post author. Hence, a collaboration
between the author of the comment (source student) and the author of the initial
post (target student) is considered. Thus, for each blog comment we can extract
one interaction, resulting in
Number of identical words : 43
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 ljljNJ additional collaborations.

As far as Twitter is concerned, collaboration among students is associated to
the reference (”@username”) and
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 re-tweet mechanisms. This was encountered
in
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 ljLjnjNj tweets, i.e., ǎNJ% of all Twitter actions. For every action presenting the
referencing mechanism, we considered a collaboration between the author of the
tweet (source student) and all the referenced students in it (target students). Thus,
a number of
Number of identical words : 36
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 ljǎNjǍ interactions were extracted from Twitter actions.

Overall, a total of
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 NJNJNJnj collaborations were extracted, yielding NJǎNj distinct
source-target pairs. Therefore, the social graph includes
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 NjNJ vertices and NJǎNj links.
In order to capture the quantitative aspects of the collaboration process, we added
a weight attribute to each link; this is equal to the number of collaborations
Number of identical words : 28
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 be-
tween the source student and target student. The range of values taken by the
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
weightwas found to be between lj and ljLjLj. A visual representation of the obtained
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

106

social graph (Base graph) is included in Figure 3.4.1.

Figure 3.4.1: Graph depicting all social media interactions among students
(Base graph). Vertices represent students and links represent collaborations

among them. The size of each vertex is proportional to its respective
eigenvector centrality value. The colour of the vertices depicts students’
clustering as determined by the modularity algorithm.
Number of identical words : 46
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Links are coloured
according to their respective source vertex.
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Graph plotting was done with
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

Gephi’s Force Atlas 2 algorithm.

By applying filtering on the
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Base graph, we were able to obtain two subgraphs
corresponding to the blog collaborations (as depicted in
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

collaborations (as depicted in
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

two graphs is the Base graph. Subsequently, each of these graphs was
Number of identical words : 19
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 analysed
through various SNA metrics, some of which are presented in Table
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

computations presented in this paper were donewithGephi network analysis tool.

107

In what follows, we discuss the collaboration patterns for each social media tool,
as reflected in the metrics and visual representations.
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

3.4.2 Results &Discussions

As defined in our conceptual framework the social network analysis, see section
3.3.2, is divided in 4 perspectives: whole graph perspective, communities perspec-
tive, individual perspective and time-series perspectives. The time series perspec-

108

Figure 3.4.3: Graph depicting students’ collaborations taking place on
Twitter (Twitter graph).

http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

respective
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 eigenvector centrality value. The colour of the vertices depicts
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
students’ clustering as determined by the modularity algorithm. Links are

coloured according to their respective source vertex.
Number of identical words : 16
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

with
Number of identical words : 5

tive is not present in the current section, as it will be introduced in section 3.5.5.
Also, youwill find that largemajority of SNAmethods/techniques identified in the
conceptual framework have been used for this analysis. Those fewmethods/tech-
niques that do appear here have been deamed unnecessary or not applicable in our
analysis.

Whole Graph Perspective

As seen in Table 3.4.1, the Twitter graph and Base graph have very similar results.
This is especially
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 due to the fact that
Number of identical words : 5
https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/the-fact-that
 Ǒǎ% of the collaboration links present in the
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

109

Table 3.4.1: SNA directed whole-graph metrics. No. communities is
determined through the modularity algorithm.

Metric Base graph Twitter graph Blog graph
No. links 263 253 117

No. SCC (strongly connected components) 1 2 6
No. communities 6 6 8
Number of identical words : 81
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

Base graph are also present in the Twitter graph (see No. links metric). By
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 com-
parison, the Blog graph contains only
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 njnj% of the total collaboration links,
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 posi-
tioning Twitter as a more comprehensive tool for collaboration. The Avg. degree
metric stands for the number of peers a student has
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 collaboratedwith ( on average).
The results depict that students engage in
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 collaborationswith other teammembers
also, since a value of 3 would have been an indication of intra-team collaboration
only. As shown by the Avg. Weighted Degree metric, collaborating students
Number of identical words : 26
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 ex-
change multiple messages, with an average of more than
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 nj with each peer. More-
over, students engage in collaborations with many more peers on Twitter than on
Blog.
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 TheDiameter and Avg. path lengthmetrics represent markers of information
diffusion in the social graph.
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 For subsequent information on the choosing of these
metrics refer to section 3.3.2 of the conceptual framework.

If we consider the complex networks’ classification method introduced in
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 pa-
per [22]
, together with the current attained metrics’ values, we can state that the
Base and Twitter graphs are of type core-periphery. In our scenario, this
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 categorisa-
tion represents a clear evidence of a learning environment that nurtures
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 informa-
tion exchange.

Density indicates the tendency of students to
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 collaboratewith peers fromother
teams. The results show that Twitter better supports such collaboration patterns,
as compared to the blog. Modularity
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 and Avg. clustering coefficient address the
division of communities that arise in social graphs. A higher modularity (range
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
[Оlj=NJ; lj]) depicts dense collaborations among community members and sparse
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

110

collaborations betweenmembers of different communities. Graphswith highAvg.
clustering coefficient (range [Lj; lj]) characterize inner communities that are close to
forming complete graphs/cliques. As it can be seen in Table
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 3.4.1, the Blog pro-
vides better support for this type of collaborations. Furthermore, No. WCC and
No. SCC also depict blog collaborations as intra-team interactions, i.e., highly
Number of identical words : 24
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 cou-
pled communities of collaboration arise on the blog. By comparing
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Figures 3.4.1,
3.4.2 and 3.4.3 we can easily notice that blog collaborations
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 aremainly established
amongmembers of the same team, as intended through the instructional scenario.
Conversely,No.
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 communitiesmetric shows that collaboration among teams is
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 bet-
ter supported by Twitter, i.e., some teams reach a high level of collaboration and
act as one larger community, as seen in
Number of identical words : 22
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Figure 3.4.3.

Based on the above discussion, we argue that both social media tools provide
adequate support for collaboration; Twitter supports both inter-team and intra-
team interactions, while Blogger mainly supports intra-team collaboration.
Number of identical words : 33
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 More-
over, both tools seem to meet the educational purposes intended in the
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 instruc-
tional scenario, as mentioned in the second section.

Communities Perspective

In what follows, we discuss in more detail the intra-team and inter-team
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 collab-
oration patterns, while highlighting salient students and teams.
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 For more details
on the methods used see section 3.3.2 of the conceptual framework. By using a
reduction transformation of the Base graph (such that vertices depicting students
are aggregated into their respective team vertex, while keeping inter-teams links),
we were able to construct the Teams graph, as shown in
Number of identical words : 37
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Figure 3.4.4. Hence, we
observe two large communities of collaboration: the first is formed by teams
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 lj
to nj ( red community), while the second is formed by teams
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Ǎ to ǐ (green com-
munity). This can be explained by
Number of identical words : 5
https://psychologenie.com/post-hoc-ergo-propter-hoc-fallacy-explained-with-examples
 the fact that teams in the red community were
scheduled in a different face-to-face session with the instructor than teams in the
green community. This means that teams
Number of identical words : 30
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 ljО nj attended each others intermediate
presentations, but not the presentations of teams
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 ǍОǐ (and the otherway around);
hence, closer ties were formed inside each community. No clear explanation arose
regarding the lower level of inter-team collaboration inside the green community,
Number of identical words : 25
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

111

compared to the red community; it should
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 bementioned however that students in
the green community had lower average marks than students in the red
Number of identical words : 16
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 commu-
nity. Thus, we argue that various external factors
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 can influence the collaboration
patterns.

Figure 3.4.4: Graph depicting collaborations established between the teams,
both on blog and Twitter (Teams graph). Vertices represent teams and links
represent inter-team collaborations. The size of each vertex is proportional to
its respective betweenness centrality value. The colour of the vertices depicts

teams’ clustering as determined by the modularity algorithm. Links are
coloured according to their respective source vertex. Links’ thickness is

proportional to their respective weight.

With the exception of Team 8members, all students engage in inter-team
Number of identical words : 80
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 col-
laboration, each teamhaving twohighly active (dominant) students. Samplegraph-
ical representations for Team 3 and Team 8 can be seen in
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Figure 3.4.5 and Figure
3.4.6 respectively.

Nevertheless, the majority of collaborations
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 (ljǍǑǐ out of NJNJNJnj or ǏNJ%) take
place among members of the same team. These results were expected, as intra-
team collaboration was required by the instructors, while inter-team collaboration
Number of identical words : 25
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

112

Figure 3.4.5: Inter-team collaborations of students from Team 3. Vertices S5,
S8, S12, S31 represent Team 3 students, while the other vertices represent
teams (T1, T2, T4-T8). Links depict collaborations among vertices and are

coloured according to their source vertex. The size of each vertex is
proportional to its respective weighted degree centrality. Links’ thickness is
proportional to their weight. Graph plotting was done with
Number of identical words : 73
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Gephi’s double

circular layout.

was only recommended. Hence, the difference can be explained by the
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 pedagog-
ical scenario and the corresponding instructors’ actions. Furthermore, we found
that all
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 teamsdisplay consistent collaboration among theirmembers, especially for
the red community. Also, every team has two dominant members for this type of
collaboration, the same students that are dominant for the inter-team
Number of identical words : 27
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 collabora-
tions ( except Team 8). Graphical representations of the intra-team collaborations
for Teams 3 and 8 can be seen in
Number of identical words : 19
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Figure 3.4.7 and Figure 3.4.8 respectively.

By studying the intra-teamand inter-teamcollaboration patterns, wewere able
to discover salient teams (T3 & T8) and students (S8 & S15). These teams and
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
studentswere chosenas they standonopposite sidesof the collaboration spectrum
and play key roles in the overall collaboration environment,
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 which we will further

coloured according to their source vertex. The size of each vertex is

proportional to its respective weighted degree centrality. Links’ thickness is
proportional to their weight. Graph plotting was done with

3.4.3 Individual Perspective

In order to discover salient students and teams we employed the graph metrics
listed in Table
Number of identical words : 16
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 3.4.2 and Table 3.4.3 respectively. We chose to present here the
results for Teams in Table 3.4.3, which as per the conceptual framework should
be under the Communities Perspective, as these are highly coupled with the results
of individual students. This specific metrics were chosen as they are
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 representa-
tive for both the topological aspects of the social graph and for the quantitative
aspects of the collaborations,
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 see section 3.3.2 of the proposed conceptual frame-
work for more details. Hubs and Authorities refer in our case to students that
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 ini-
tiate many collaborations (source students), respectively to students that are
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 in-
volved in many collaborations initiated by others (target students); i.e., students
that share knowledge versus those that receive knowledge. Betweenness
Number of identical words : 20
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 empha-
sises students that act as bridges of collaboration, i.e., they facilitate collaboration
among peers that otherwise are part of different communities. As seen in
Number of identical words : 24
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Figures
3.4.1, 3.4.4 and 3.4.5, members of Team3 appear to act as a communication bridge
between other teams. Furthermore, in our scenario we interpret Closeness
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 as a
marker of involvement in the overall collaboration of the respective graph.
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Eigen-
vector and PageRank determine the influence of a
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 student’s position in the collabo-
ration graph. Weighted In-degree andWeighted Out-degree count for the number of
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

115

Table 3.4.2: SNA directed graph metrics for vertices, SX stands for Student
X.
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 Closeness on the Blog graph was considered only for the giant component.

All computations were done with Gephi network analysis tool.

As mentioned in section 3.4.2 and also shown in Table
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 3.4.2, student S8 can
be considered as the top ranked student (collaboration-wise). In order to explain
her almost unchallenged top
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 rankingwe conducted further investigations. Univer-
sity records show she was involved in two long-duration foreign exchange projects
in different locations, which could suggest a highly social person. Her peers
Number of identical words : 24
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 con-
firmed that S8 is indeed a very sociable and talkative learner. By conducting an
interview with the student, we determined that she was actively engaged in social
media, managing a globetrotter blog. Furthermore, she has participated in formal
Number of identical words : 38
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

116

and informal training on social media techniques. Hence, we reached a potential
explanation of the high collaboration rankings achieved.

Moreover, student S8 is part of team T3, which can also be considered as the
leading team from a collaboration point of view. The importance of this team can
be explained by two factors. First, by looking at
Number of identical words : 59
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

Table
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

orations; however, the team is not placed in the top 3 according to
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

Degreemetric. Hence, we argue thatT3 is actively sharingmore knowledge than it
receives, supposition confirmed to some extent by
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

metrics in Table
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

tion paths, as can be seen also in
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

positioning factors make this team the highest ranked collaboration-wise.
