3.5 StudentViz: ATool forVisualizing Students’Collabo-
rations

Thus far in the current chapter, we have proposed a conceptual framework for
knowledge extraction and
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 visualisation based on SNA in section 3.3 and paper
[24]
, which we have validated in
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 section 3.4 and paper [25]
. Gephi network anal-
ysis tool was used for all computations and graph
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visualisations, which adequately
fitted researcher’s needs; however, the tool was deemed too complex for
Number of identical words : 11
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 instruc-
tors, who are not specialists in SNA or
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visualisation.

Therefore, we decided to build a simple network
Number of identical words : 8
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visualisation tool, easy to use
by the teachers and specifically designed to work in conjunction with
Number of identical words : 15
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 eMUSE so-
cial learning environment. The tool should provide useful and relevant
Number of identical words : 9
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visualisa-
tions from the instructor’s point of view, therefore we first identified a list of
Number of identical words : 14
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visu-
alisation needs (VN) outlined by the teachers working with eMUSE:

VN1
Number of identical words : 11
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 Visualise the general status of collaboration.

VN2 Visualize the status of collaboration for each community.

VN3 Visualize the status of collaboration for each learner.
Number of identical words : 25
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0

117

Furthermore, the tool should support the processes of gaining insight through
information
Number of identical words : 12
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visualisations, as identified in [233]
:

P1 Provide Overview - grasp the big picture of a dataset.

P2 Adjust - explore
Number of identical words : 15
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 adataset by changing the abstraction level or selection range
(e.g., by filtering, grouping, aggregating).

P3 Detect Pattern - find relationships, trends, or anomalies in the dataset.

P4
Number of identical words : 28
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 MatchMentalModel - correlate the data with the user’s mental model of it,
in order to facilitate understanding.

Starting
Number of identical words : 17
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 fromthese requirements, wedesignedand implementedourStudentViz
tool, as described further.

3.5.1 Related Visualisation Platforms

Manynetwork visualisation platforms (NVP) are available [46]
; however, they are
not specifically built for educational settings, so we wanted to investigate whether
they can be used for our particular learning scenario, in conjunction with eMUSE
platform. As our target users are instructors with limited technical expertise, we
imposed some initial restrictions. The considered tools should be free, easy to
Number of identical words : 52
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 in-
stall and use, and operating system independent. Moreover, they should provide
high flexibility, so that instructors could adapt the
Number of identical words : 18
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visualisation methods to their
needs. Hence, our evaluation included the following platforms:

• Cuttlefish
Number of identical words : 12
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 10 focuses on ease of use, butwith limited capabilities andnoflexi-
bility; wealso experienced somevisualisationglitchesuponusing the zoom-
ing functionality.

• Cytoscape is an open source platform developed for molecular networks
Number of identical words : 9
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
visualisation, that has expanded its use across various network related
Number of identical words : 9
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 re-
search fields [200]
. Its standard features are relatively easy to use. However,
the platform lacks flexibility of the
Number of identical words : 15
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visualisation methods.

• Visione11 has similar capabilities with Cytoscape, but it provides even less
Number of identical words : 10
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
10http://cuttlefish.sourceforge.net/
11https://visone.info/

118

flexibility and the user interface is cluttered and non-intuitive.

• Tulip
Number of identical words : 11
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 is an NVP that focuses on relational data [9]
. It provides highly flexi-
ble visualisationandawide rangeof analysis capabilities for various research
fields.

• Gephi
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 aims tobe a general platformof analysis and visualisation for all kinds
of networks
Number of identical words : 5
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 [19]
. Its clear design and resemblance with
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 Photoshopmake it
very easy to use. Furthermore, its
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 visualisation capabilities are flexible and
extensible through plugins.

Overall, we found Gephi and Tulip to be equally capable in terms of
Number of identical words : 20
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 visual-
isation functionalities; however, Gephi provided a better user experience.
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 Nev-
ertheless, all platforms were considered too complex by the instructors,
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 includ-
ing many irrelevant functionalities for their purpose and requiring SNA expertise.
Also, some of the desired
Number of identical words : 15
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 visualisations ( e.g., team and community perspectives)
required significant effort in order to be generated with the existing NVP, starting
from our available eMUSE dataset. Therefore, we decided to build a network
Number of identical words : 31
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 vi-
sualisation tool dedicated for the teachers, with a simple and intuitive interface, as
described next.
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf

3.5.2 Data Acquisition &Graph BuildingModule

StudentViz is a data visualisation tool purposely built to work in conjunction with
Number of identical words : 8
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
eMUSE social learning environment. Its aim is to provide suggestive
Number of identical words : 10
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visualisations
of students’ collaboration patterns, as they are recorded by the platform.
Number of identical words : 11
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 All stu-
dents’ social media traces are monitored and stored by eMUSE, and StudentViz
uses these data to draw the graphs depicting social media interactions between the
students. A schematic representation of the data flow is shown in
Number of identical words : 35
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 Figure 3.5.1.

Basedon the conceptual frameworksprinciplesof constructing the social graph,
see section3.3.1, andprevious experiencewithbuilding social graphs from eMUSE
data, see section3.4.1, adata acquisition&graphbuildingmodule (denotedDtoG)
was developed to bridge the gap between the data source (eMUSE) and the
Number of identical words : 11
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visual-
isation tool (StudentViz). DtoG processes the raw data collected by eMUSE,
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 filter-

119

Figure 3.5.1: StudentViz - network visualisation data flow.

ing the collaboration actions, and then creates various social graphs on which
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 sev-
eral SNAmethods are applied. More specifically, directed graphs are built starting
from students’ interactions on the Blog and
Number of identical words : 16
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 micro-blogging tool (Twitter); nodes
represent learners and links represent messages exchanged through the social
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 me-
dia tools integrated in eMUSE. These graphs can be exported in various formats
(e.g., .gml or .json files), which can be subsequently input into
Number of identical words : 20
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 anyNVP, including
StudentViz. As far as implementation is concerned, DtoG was built using Python
3.5 programming language
Number of identical words : 16
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 andNetworkX graph analysis library.

As part of the the DtoG module several edge/link weighting methods were
developed in order to capture collaboration from various facets. The first method
wNC, see Equation 3.1, computes the weight of an edge as the number of collab-
orations between two students. Although, this is the most usual method used
in the academia it fails to capture the qualitative aspects of collaboration, which
we will try to capture through the subsequent equations. From our perspective,
the re-tweeting mechanism (RT) is used to emphasise a useful piece of informa-
tion, therefor collaborations containing such a mechanism should receive a heav-
ier weight, see Equation 3.2. wRTmethod rewards the student that re-tweets the
message, he/she is perceived as a person that strengthens collaboration through
reviewing a message content and passing it along. Regarding the wLK method,

120

see Equation 3.3, students consider sharing internet links as an efficientmanner of
collaboration; it requires minimal time effort, from the perspective of the contrib-
utor, and high input of information, from the perspective of the recipient. Further
more, this sharingmethod is suitable for Twitter due to themessage length restric-
tion. The wALLmethod encapsulates both qualitative and quantitative aspects of
the collaborations in case. The values of α and β were experimentally deducted
with a higher emphasis on students that review and share information; hence the
higher value of α. Note that the wRTmethod only makes sense when Twitter col-
laborations are taken in consideration.

wNCedge(A;B) = No:collaborations(A;B) (3.1)

wRTedge(A;B) =
No:collaborations(A;B)X

n=lj
collaborationn О α (3.2)

wLKedge(A;B) =
No:collaborations(A;B)X

n=lj
collaborationn О β (3.3)

wALLedge(A;B) =
No:collaborations(A;B)X

n=lj
collaborationn О α О β (3.4)

α =

8>>><>>>:lj if collaborationn is not RTNj if collaborationn is RT
β =

8>>><>>>:lj if collaborationn does not contain an internet linkNJ if collaborationn contains an internet link
Collaborations present in the Base graph, see section 3.4.1, can be filtered by

their source, established on Twitter or Blogger. Hence, we can construct a col-
laboration graph for each social media platform and compare their traits. Also, we

121

considered applying the twograph transformationmethods: reduction and context;
which we have discussed in section 3.3.2.

To be able to conduct temporal analysis, we need to construct graphs of col-
laborations established during specific time frames. We established the length of
a time frame to be 2 weeks, as students met with the instructors every other week.
Hence, such a time frame is adequate to see progress between instructor-student
encounters. The construction of temporal graph is identical with the construction
of the Base graph, after restricting the set of collaborations to those established
during the specified time frame. As the course spans for ljnjweeks there are Ǐ non-
overlapping time frames. However, we need to consider the two weeks of winter
vacation, as student may still be active. We will further mention them as TFx, x
stands for the starting week. Hence, TF1 is the time frame starting with day one
of the first week and ending with day seven of the second week. Similarly, TF7 is
a 2-week time frame starting with day one of week Ǐ. In order to address the time
frame of the entire semester we will mark it as Tall.

We developed the following graph naming schema: source_weighting-method
_timeframe_[transformation-method]; as a concise andclearwayofdescribinggraphs.
The source can be: twitter, blogger or all; standing for the social media source
of the collaborations, all stands for both twitter and blogger collaborations. See
Equations3.1 to3.4 for thepossibleweightingmethods. The transformationmethod
canbe: reduction, context[team]ornone. Where the teamparameter in context[team]
represents the IDof a eMUSE team. Upon the use of context[team], a context trans-
formation of the attained graph with the focus on a specific eMUSE team shall
be applied, e.g., context2. For example, the graph twitter_wALL_T5_context3 is
a graph forged from messages gathered on Twitter during week 5 and 6. Further
more, the edge weighting method wALL takes in consideration re-tweets and the
presence of internet links while putting an emphasis on team 3. The scope of forg-
ing this graph is to allow instructors to analyse the collaboration activity onTwitter
for students in team 3 during week 5 and 6, with a special regard for those that re-
view and share information as internet links. It is noteworthy that the DtoGmod-
ule generates automatically all possible graphs, the instructor needs only to run the
module and understand the naming schema.

122

3.5.3 StudentViz Design

General Design

In an attempt to reduce instructors’ effort in using StudentViz, we decided to con-
ceive it as
Number of identical words : 17
https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0.pdf
 awebapplication, thus eliminating theneedof installation, configuration
and manual updates. PHP, HTML5, CSS and Cytoscape
Number of identical words : 11
https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0.pdf
 12 JavaScript library were
used for implementing the tool.

We also discussed with the instructors in order to agree on a set of graph
Number of identical words : 23
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 plot-
ting conventions that would be most suitable for their needs.
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 The visualisation
methods should be easily correlated with humans’ mental map (insight gaining
process P4
Number of identical words : 14
https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0.pdf
 [233]
), thus reducing the comprehension effort. Therefore, we used
directed graphs, in which nodes represent learners and links represent messages
sent between the learners (on Blog or Twitter). In order to expand the dimen-
sionality of the information rendered in the graph, we introduced a
Number of identical words : 44
https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0.pdf
 colour schema
and magnitude schema for each graph element. Nodes shall be
Number of identical words : 11
https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0.pdf
 coloured accord-
ing to their affiliation to a certain community, i.e., nodes representing learners of
the same team / community shall have the same
Number of identical words : 21
https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0.pdf
 colour. In addition, links shall
be
Number of identical words : 5
https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0.pdf
 coloured according to their source node, in order to represent link direction.
For example, if student A (red-
Number of identical words : 17
https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0.pdf
 coloured node) sent amessage to student B (green-
coloured node), then the link between nodes A
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0.pdf
 andB shall be coloured in red. The
magnitude of each node (i.e., diameter) shall be directly proportional to a chosen
SNA ranking: the larger the node, the higher the ranking. Thus, instructors can
easily compare students according to a selected SNA ranking method, e.g.,
Number of identical words : 42
https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0.pdf
 PageR-
ank [173]
. In order tomap the node to a particular learner, nodes shall be
Number of identical words : 9
https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0.pdf
 labelled
with a unique learner ID.
Number of identical words : 5
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 Furthermore, the thickness of each link shall be directly
proportional to the strength / intensity of the collaboration between the two
Number of identical words : 19
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 stu-
dents; as computed described in Equations 3.1 to 3.4.

We also decided to use force
Number of identical words : 6
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 directedmethods (FDM) for graphplotting [88]
,
which generally produce aesthetically pleasing results. These methods are based
on attractive and repulsive forces inspired from physics. Such forces attract nodes
with high connectivity and repulse those with low connectivity, making the
Number of identical words : 33
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 ob-
servation of communities of collaboration very intuitive. Moreover, the distance
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf

12http://js.cytoscape.org/

123

among nodes is inversely correlated with the strength of their influence on each
other. Another advantage of FDM is their adaptability to various network traits,
so they can be
Number of identical words : 29
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 optimised from case to case.

Visual Design

StudentViz interface was designed in a simple and intuitive way. Two views are
available, similar to Gephi: the Main view and the Data view. The Main view is
further divided into 3 areas: Options area (left side), Plotting canvas area
Number of identical words : 40
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 (centre)
and Additional information area (right side). Figure
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 3.5.2 provides a screenshot of
StudentViz Main view,
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 see Figure 3.5.3. The Data view consists of a sortable grid
of learners’ attributes, including various SNA metrics. Similar views can also be
found in Gephi, Cytoscape or Tulip under various names (e.g., Data laboratory in
Gephi).
Number of identical words : 35
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf

Figure 3.5.2: StudentViz Main view - Focus-circular layout is employed;
nodes’ diameters are proportional to their PageRank, while their
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 colours depict

affiliation to a specific team.
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf

In what follows we present the Main view in more detail. The Options area
allows instructors to interact with the
Number of identical words : 20
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 visualisations and adjust them through var-
ious settings. Thus, as collaboration cannot be quantified by just one
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 SNAmetric,
the teacher has the possibility to choose from several metrics: Betweenness,
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 Close-

124

Figure 3.5.3: StudentViz Data view.

ness, Degree, In-Degree, Out-degree, Eigenvector
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 andPageRank. ThroughBetweenness
an instructor can determine the students that bridge community silos, those that
facilitate the exchange of knowledge between communities. Students with high
Closeness values are positioned on various communication paths, playing an
Number of identical words : 32
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 im-
portant role in knowledge diffusion. Degree, In-Degree and Out-Degree centrality
metrics can be used to determine the most / least active learners. Both
Number of identical words : 23
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 Eigenvec-
tor and PageRank are measures of nodes importance that take into consideration
qualitative and quantitative aspects; an important student is defined as one that
has multiple collaborations with other important students. Additional
Number of identical words : 31
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 informa-
tion about these centrality metrics can be found in
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 [34]
.

Another functionality provided in theOptions area allows the instructor to
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 se-
lect the graph plotting algorithm; available choices are: WebCola
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 13, Cose-Bilkent
[67]
, Circular and Focus-circular, which will be
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 further discussed. Furthermore,
the instructor can also choose the focus of the
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 visualisation: individual learners,
teams or communities. This functionality is achieved by applying a reduction
Number of identical words : 13
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 trans-
formation on graphs that include all students; learners of the same team are
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 repre-

13http://marvl.infotech.monash.edu/webcola

125

sented as onenode, while filtering out intra-teamcollaborations. Furthermore, the
nodes’ colour can depict team or community affiliation; teams are predetermined
from the beginning of the semester, while communities are non-formal and self-
regulated. Community detection is computed using a Laplacian method
Number of identical words : 31
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 [131]
.

An additional option available to the instructor is to load various graphs
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 cre-
atedby theDtoGmodule (e.g., graphcontaining all socialmedia interactions among
students, graph containing only collaborations on the Blog / Twitter). Finally,
for easy identification of each student / team, an
Number of identical words : 20
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 auto-complete search box is pro-
vided, in addition to the full list of students.

The
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 central area of theMain view consists of a black canvas
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 onwhich the graph
is plotted. The canvas
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 colour was chosen in order to provide a high contrast for the
graph nodes and edges. The instructor can
Number of identical words : 18
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 re-position nodes through drag-and-
drop functionality; he can also select one node for detailed inspection, which sets
the graph plotting algorithm to Focus-circular and opens
Number of identical words : 26
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 theAdditional information
area.

Finally, the right side area of
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 theMain view provides information regarding the
specific node selected: student name, team,
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 SNAmetrics values. This area is only
displayed upon selection of a node, otherwise it is hidden, to allocate a larger space
for the plotting canvas
Number of identical words : 24
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf

3.5.4 Illustrating Visualisation Functionalities in StudentViz

In what follows we show how StudentViz answers instructors’
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 visualisation needs,
as they were specified in the Introduction (VN1 - VN3). It also provides support
for the general processes through which people gain insight when using an
Number of identical words : 28
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 infor-
mation visualisation system (P1 - P4)
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 [233]
.

The context of use is a course
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 onWeb Applications Design, taught to 4th year
undergraduate students from the University of Craiova, Romania, during 2016-
2017winter semester.
Number of identical words : 20
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 NjNJ students used eMUSEplatform( and the associated social
media tools) for communication and collaboration support.
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 Based on the social
media traces
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 collectedby eMUSE, a total ofNJNJNJnj collaboration linkswere extracted
(NJǎNj having distinct source-target pairs). Therefore, a social
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 graphwith NjNJ vertices
and NJǎNj links was built.

126

Thus, Figures 3.5.4 and 3.5.5 provide a birds-eye view on learners’
Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 collabora-
tion, by usingCose-Bilkent andWebCola FDM respectively. These algorithms have
low computational workload in case of small graphs and are suited for interactive
applications, as they avoid the overlapping of nodes. As seen in Fig. 3 and 4, the
general pattern of collaboration can be easily spotted, thus supporting VN1 and
P1. High and low density areas of collaboration can be easily identified in both
figures. Learners in the high density area (with nodes tightly plotted together) are
significantly involved in collaboration with members of diverse teams; students
in low density areas are those that teachers should focus on in order to enhance
collaboration.
Number of identical words : 101
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf

Figure 3.5.4: Visualisation provided by StudentViz using Cose-Bilkent
plotting method. Nodes’ diameters are proportional to PageRank metric, while

their
Number of identical words : 17
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 colours depict affiliation to a specific team.
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf

Although both algorithms produce similar
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 visualisations, there are some vari-
ations that justify their complementary use. WebCola favors the identification of
large communities of collaboration, as nodes are plotted in close proximity.
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 How-
ever, this creates clutter, making smaller communities (teams) hard to spot. In
turn, Cose-Bilkent favors the observation of smaller communities over large ones.
Hence,WebCola and Cose-Bilkent also support VN2. In addition, these methods
Number of identical words : 36
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf

127

Figure 3.5.5: Visualisation provided by StudentViz using WebCola layout.
Nodes’ diameters are proportional to PageRank metric, while their colors

depict affiliation to a specific community.
Number of identical words : 22
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf

allow the discovery of the general structure and trends of collaboration, thus
Number of identical words : 12
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 ad-
dressing P3.

Furthermore, instructors canbetter assess the collaborationbetween the teams
by visualising teams as nodes, like in
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 Figure 3.5.6 (whichwas obtained by applying
the graph reduction transformation). Both
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 Figure 3.5.2 and Figure 3.5.6 are illustra-
tions of the Focus-circular plottingmethod, devised to clearly observe the status of
a particular node (learner or team, respectively).
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 Thenode of interest is positioned
in the center of a circle on which the other nodes are plotted. Moreover, only the
collaborations that involve the node of interest are rendered, to reduce
Number of identical words : 31
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
 unneces-
sary clutter and allow the instructor to focus on the particular node. Hence, these
focus-circular
Number of identical words : 15
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visualisations address both VN2 (when nodes represent teams) and
VN3 (when nodes represent students). Furthermore, P2 is also supported, as
Number of identical words : 22
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 in-
structors can change the perspective on the
Number of identical words : 6
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 data-set by selecting the node of
Number of identical words : 5
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 inter-
est.

Finally, the Circular plotting method, inspired by Gephi’s circular layout, was
devised
Number of identical words : 13
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 tobetterobserve the statusof each team, as illustrated inFigure3.5.7. First,
an average value of the selected
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 SNAmetric is computed for each team. The team
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0

128

Figure 3.5.6: Visualisation provided by StudentViz using Focus-circular
layout. Nodes represent teams and their diameters are proportional to

PageRank metric.
Number of identical words : 18
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0

with the highest ranking is plotted first, followed by the other teams according to
their average metric rank, in a clockwise descending order. Individual nodes are
also rendered in a clockwise descending order in the designated plot area for their
team, according to their SNA metric value. Hence, the first plotted node depicts
the learner with the highest selected metric value from the highest ranking team.
This
Number of identical words : 67
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 visualisation method allows the teacher to observe the status of each team in
comparison with other teams, but also the status of each learner in comparison
with his
Number of identical words : 27
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 fellow team members. Thus, both VN2 and VN3 are addressed by this
Number of identical words : 14
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSLE_2018.pdf
visualisation method; moreover, P3 is supported here, as instructors can discover
collaboration patterns among teams and students.
Number of identical words : 17
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0

3.5.5 Insights obtained through StudentViz

Through the use of StudentViz we were able to gather valuable insights, out of
which we will discuss some. By presenting these insights and their manner of
discovery we
Number of identical words : 10
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 hope to provide better evidence on the utility of our proposed tool.
Number of identical words : 11
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
These insights refer to the data in question, however we argue that similar
Number of identical words : 5
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 or even
additional insights could be obtained no matter the data/context.

As mentioned before, StudentViz also has a Data view, which a tabular rep-

129

Figure 3.5.7: Visualisation provided by StudentViz using Circular layout.
Nodes’ diameters are proportional to PageRank metric, while their
Number of identical words : 15
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 colours

depict affiliation to a specific team.
Number of identical words : 6
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0

resentation of data on each student/team. The data represent numerical values
computed for various SNA metrics. Hence, for each student/team the Data view
presents a comprehensive numerical status. However, the real utility of this view
is the ability
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 of compare and rank students/teams according to the SNA metrics
considered. Hence,
Number of identical words : 12
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 an instructor can observe the
Number of identical words : 5
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 student’s performance in com-
parison with others and perceive themagnitude of the differences through the
Number of identical words : 5
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 de-
picted values. We chose to present theData view here as it is a good starting point
for
Number of identical words : 6
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 each discovering insights, as we shall exemplify in the following lines. In our
experience of working with StudentViz and other similar platforms, we were able
to discover insights by observing some particularities in Data view and then con-
firming them inMain view or vice versa.

One of the insights revealed as we were analysing students as part of their re-
spective team. To do so, we ranked the students in Data view by Team. Hence,
we were able to observe the performance of each teammember, compared to each
other, and the general distribution of their social metrics’ values. An instructor
with this insight on teams coulddevise targetedmethods for theunder-performing
teams. Such teams can also be identified by observing theMain View. For exam-
ple, in Figure 3.5.6. you can observe a graph that depicts communication between
Number of identical words : 6
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0

130

teams, aggregated communication among student of different teams. As the the
diameter of the nodes is tied with the PageRank metric, the larger the node the
Number of identical words : 8
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
more social is the respective team. Hence, another way or a complementary way
to observe teams’ status.

Through the help of the DtoG module, StudentViz is able to provide the
Number of identical words : 12
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 in-
structors with visualisations and data not only for the entire
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 period of time, but
for specific time periods also, see Figures 3.5.8 and 3.5.9 for exemplification. Such
capability can provide valuable insights on the development
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 of the entire learn-
ing/ collaboration network. By looking at the inter-
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 teams collaboration patterns
that form higher order communities, we
Number of identical words : 8
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 observed that teams forming stable com-
munities ( over time) have more intense social interactions. Hence, collaboration
among teams
Number of identical words : 11
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 is good when it is relatively stable/lasting,
Number of identical words : 6
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 e.g. teams 1 & 3. In order
to sustain our observation, we computed a tabular manner of representing com-
munity formation in our scenario, see Table 3.5.1. The table was computed by
loading the following graphs: all_t5, all_t7, all_t9 & all_t11; and colouring the
nodes based on their Partition. Hence, we could visualise the communities of stu-
dents that were present in the weeks 5&6, 7&8, 9&10 and 11&12. Than, we in-
cluded the initial team allocation which could be found in the Data view as
Number of identical words : 5
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 Team
id. In the above mentioned Table we can see that teams 1 & 3 form a community
(backbone) from start to finish, hence they collaborate in a stable manner.
Number of identical words : 22
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 The
community formed by the above mentioned teams is joined in TF 3 by team 4,
which
Number of identical words : 5
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 we’ll be sustained also in TF 4 with the exception of one student. Team 2
is generally forming
Number of identical words : 12
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 it’s own community with the exception of
Number of identical words : 6
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 TF2, when it was
part of the backbone community.
Number of identical words : 5
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 Team 4 started on its own and ended as part
of the backbone community, with the exception of
Number of identical words : 5
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 one student, a case for future
work. Hence, we can argue that collaboration among teams 1 – 4 is relatively
Number of identical words : 12
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 sta-
ble, at least compared with teams 5 – 8.
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 Also note that teams 1 – 4 have the highest
PageRank values
Number of identical words : 5
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 and that visualisations of Figures 3.5.4, 3.5.5 & 3.5.7 clearly show
that they collaborate substantially. For Team 5 and Team 8 the inter-team collab-
oration patterns have similarities, both teams have tried to collaborate with other
teams but no collaboration
Number of identical words : 8
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 was sustained for more than one
Number of identical words : 5
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 time-frame. How-
ever there are some substantial differences, team 5 is depicted in the majority of
plots as sustaining a closer collaboration with Teams 1-4 than teams 6 – 8, hence
Number of identical words : 25
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0

131

we consider this team to be the most collaborative among teams 5-8.
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 Team 8 is
at the opposite
Number of identical words : 6
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 spectrum of collaboration, very few collaborations are established
outside the team. Team 5 & 6 and try various collaborations with other teams,
however no stable communities are formed (lasting at least two consecutive
Number of identical words : 17
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 time
frames). Based on the above observations we could identify 3 general collabora-
tion patterns for our scenario. Teams that collaborate in a stable manner (teams
Number of identical words : 9
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
1,3,4), teams that collaborate but not in a
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 stablemanner (teams 2,5,6,7) and teams
that barely collaborate (team 8).
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0

Figure 3.5.8: Visualisation provided by StudentViz using Cose-Bilkent layout.
Nodes represent students and their diameters are proportional to PageRank

metric,
Number of identical words : 18
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 the graphs was constructed only based on the communication
established in the 5th and 6th week of the course.

Since the students in our class are able to communicate by using Twitter and
Blogger we provide the instructors the possibility to visualise/analyse the collab-
orations established on each social media tool and aggregated collaborations. T
his functionality is provided by the DtoG module and not by StudentViz per se.
Thus, instructors can evaluate students not only on the entire collaboration spec-
trum but for specific collaborations also. For our scenario, having insights on how
students/teams rank by social media tool has sense, as the tools were introduced
to support different types of communication with each having specific purposes.

132

Figure 3.5.9: Visualization provided by StudentViz using Cose-Bilkent
Number of identical words : 7
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 layout.
Nodes represent students and their diameters are proportional to PageRank

metric,
Number of identical words : 12
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0
 the graphs was constructde only based on the communication
established in the 11th and 12th weeks of the course

Twitter has the role of support non-formal, fast exchange of communicationwhich
mainly consists of opinions and internet links, this was also the preferred commu-
nication method of the students. On the other part, Blogger collaborations are
more formal since the authors need to write longer and scientifically wise texts.
Also, blogger posts were written when key milestones were reached during the
projects’ development phases. Hence, we consider that a good collaboration be-
tween the students should also be reflected both on Twitter and Blogger. As you
can see in Figures 10 and 11 the above conclusion is true for some teams, while for
other teams only Twitter plays the major role as collaboration tool.

engaged in a project-based learning activity during 6 consecutive

The analyses indicated that students who received higher grades in the course
had greater word entropy, used more verbs, prepositions, adverbs, and pronouns,
produced more unique words, and more named entities. Additionally, students
who received higher grades had lower inner cohesion per contribution,
Number of identical words : 46
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf

ingmore elaborated paragraphs that represented amixture of different ideas in the
context of each
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 contribution. The time series variables denote
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 amore uniformdis-
tribution, with weekly fluctuations in terms of participation, which is normal for
students that were more actively involved in using the social media tools. Three of
these variables (word entropy, time series entropy and average verbs in sentence)
were predictive of performance in both a regression analysis and a DFA. The
Number of identical words : 47
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf
 re-
sults are promising as several significant correlations and statistical models were
Number of identical words : 10
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf

134

identified in order to predict academic performance (i.e., course grades) based on
textual complexity and longitudinal analysis indices. Additional experiments that

dents from the total of 343 course participants and will increase the power of the
applied mechanisms.

http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf

Number of identical words : 7
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ECTEL_2016.pdf

students engaged in a project-based learning activity. The results are
Number of identical words : 36
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf

Number of identical words : 14

tion) was determined to be a significant predictor. Similarly, several indexes were
predictive for three of the four FSLSM dimensions: two predictors for the
Number of identical words : 23
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf

tive/ reflective dimension, three predictors for the visual/verbal dimension, and
one predictor for the sequential/global dimension; no variables were predictive of
the sensing/intuitive dimension. As expected, since the students’ online
Number of identical words : 32
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf

pation was directly linked to the project grading, it was normal that the effect size
for scoring projects is greater
Number of identical words : 19
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf
 in contrast to the evaluation relying on the final exam
grades.

small sample size; therefore, its power is low. Nevertheless, the employed
Number of identical words : 35
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICALT_2016.pdf

nisms are extensible and can be easily applied on a larger student population.

3.6.2 Conclusions on the use of SNAmethods

As part of this chapter, we have introduced a conceptual knowledge extraction
framework to explore the collaborative learning process supported by eMUSE
Number of identical words : 15
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 en-
vironment and the integrated social media tools. A set of knowledge extraction
methods based on SNA techniques were proposed, starting from specific
Number of identical words : 21
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 educa-
tional needs identified by the instructor. The social graph built from student
Number of identical words : 11
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 in-
teractions on the social media tools was
Number of identical words : 6
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf
 analysed at several levels of granularity
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

135

( whole graph, communities and individual perspective). While we acknowledge
that our framework is not exhaustive, we believe that the selected methods could
prove useful in similar social learning scenarios.
Number of identical words : 29
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICCC_2017.pdf

Next we experimentally validated the proposed conceptual knowledge
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 extrac-
tion framework on eMUSE platform. We were able to satisfy, to some extent, the
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
pedagogical knowledge needs mentioned Table 3.3.1. In section 3.4.1, we man-
aged to determine the collaboration network and quantify collaborations over
Number of identical words : 9
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 sev-
eral graph granularities (KN1 and KN2). By
Number of identical words : 8
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 analysing various traits of the collab-
oration process through SNA metrics, we
Number of identical words : 5
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 emphasised salient students and teams
(KN3). Through detecting communities of collaboration, we were able to better
comprehend the collaboration patterns (KN2-6). Our analyses showed that the
course environment adequately supports both intra-team and inter-team
Number of identical words : 38
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 collab-
oration ( KN4). We argued that students’ knowledge level, background in using
social media and face-to-face meetings might have an impact on the collaboration
patterns, as proof of the influence of external factors (KN5). We also observed the
impact of the instructional scenario and teachers’ instructions on promoting intra-
team collaborations (KN6). Finally, by providing social graph plots and ranked
lists of students, we managed to present the extracted knowledge in a clear and
comprehensive way (KN7). Therefore, we successfully validated the proposed
conceptual knowledge extraction framework on our eMUSE social learning
Number of identical words : 96
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf
 envi-
ronment. Nevertheless, we acknowledge that further research is required in order
to fully satisfy instructors’ knowledge needs.
Number of identical words : 16
http://software.ucv.ro/~epopescu/docs/publications/ICSTCC_2017.pdf

As a further commitment we developed StudentViz, throughwhich an average
computer literate instructor is able to observe the collaboration status on differ-
ent levels of network granularity, to
Number of identical words : 16
https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0.pdf

learners / teams; also, studies can be conducted by filtering the collaborations
by media source and/or
Number of identical words : 33
https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40561-018-0063-0.pdf
